# THESIS DRAFT

- **(Q1)** What is the influence of the regional environment on semi-natural grasslands and heathlands? More specifically:
  - **(Q1-1)** Can we confirm the hump-shaped productivity pattern along the coast-to-mountain gradient (**paper IV**)?
  - **(Q1-2)** Can we detect the influence of geographic or climatic factors on the taxonomic and functional composition of semi-natural grasslands (**paper II**, **paper III**, **paper IV**)?
- **(Q2)** What are the synergies and trade-offs between indicators of biodiversity and ecosystem services among semi-natural grasslands and heathlands (**paper II**, **paper III**, **paper IV**)?
- **(Q3)** Which management factor influences the diversity and community composition of semi-natural grasslands and heathlands? More specifically:
  - **(Q3-1)** Is there an effect of livestock type or grazing intensity on diversity and community composition in semi-natural grasslands (**paper II**, **paper III**)?
  - **(Q3-2)** How prescribed burning supports the conservation of semi-natural heathlands (**paper I**, **paper IV**)?* øøø


## EXTRA TABLE

```{r FieldRegio}
#| label: tbl-fieldregio
#| tbl-cap: "Statistical medians and ranges (in brackets) of climate and elevation data for the 42 visited grazing fields according to the landscape zonation. Climate data source: Mean values of daily projections with 1 km^2^ resolution for the period 2010-2020 from the Norwegian Centre for Climate Services (CC BY 3.0). Elevation data: collected on site."
#| message: false
#| warning: false

library(gt)
library(tidyverse)
library(purrr)

ecozone <- read.csv("data/cleandata/NBR_FullSiteInfo.csv")
elevation <- read.csv("data/cleandata/NBR_FullArea20x20.csv")
landuse <- read.csv("data/cleandata/NBR_FullLanduse.csv")
climate <- read.csv("data/cleandata/NBR_FullClimate.csv")

# Data table
regio <- purrr::reduce(list(subset(ecozone, select = c(SiteID, EcoZone)), subset(elevation, select = c(SiteID, Elevation)), subset(landuse, select = c(SiteID, FieldType)), climate), dplyr::full_join)

# Remove unused sites
regio <- filter(regio, SiteID != "UC1" & SiteID != "UG1" & SiteID != "UG2")

# Summary variables
regio <- regio |> 
  group_by(EcoZone) |> 
  summarise(
    mediantemp = format(round(median(avgtempJuly), 1), nsmall =1),
    mintemp = format(round(min(avgtempJuly), 1), nsmall =1),
    maxtemp = format(round(max(avgtempJuly), 1), nsmall =1),
    mediantrange = format(round(median(maxtempJuly - mintempJan), 1), nsmall =1),
    mintrange = format(round(min(maxtempJuly - mintempJan), 1), nsmall =1),
    maxtrange = format(round(max(maxtempJuly - mintempJan), 1), nsmall =1),
    medianpreci = format(round(median(annualprecipitation), 0), nsmall =0),
    minpreci = format(round(min(annualprecipitation), 0), nsmall =0),
    maxpreci = format(round(max(annualprecipitation), 0), nsmall =0),
    medianelev = format(round(median(Elevation), 0), nsmall =0),
    minelev = format(round(min(Elevation), 0), nsmall =0),
    maxelev = format(round(max(Elevation), 0), nsmall =0)
  ) |> 
  mutate(
    temp = paste(mediantemp, " (", mintemp, " - ", maxtemp, ")", sep = ""),
    trange = paste(mediantrange, " (", mintrange, " - ", maxtrange, ")", sep = ""),
    preci = paste(medianpreci, " (", minpreci, " - ", maxpreci, ")", sep = ""),
    elev = paste(medianelev, " (", minelev, " - ", maxelev, ")", sep = "")
  )

# gt friendly variables
regiogt <- regio |> 
  pivot_longer(cols = c(temp, trange, preci, elev), names_to = "Variable", values_to = "Values")
regiogt <- subset(regiogt, select = c(EcoZone, Variable, Values))
regiogt <- regiogt |> 
  pivot_wider(names_from = EcoZone, values_from = Values) |> 
  mutate(Variable = dplyr::recode(Variable, "temp" = "July temperature (°C)"),
         Variable = dplyr::recode(Variable, "trange" = "Maximal temperature range (°C)"),
         Variable = dplyr::recode(Variable, "preci" = "Annual precipitation (mm)"),
         Variable = dplyr::recode(Variable, "elev" = "Elevation (masl)"))

# gt table
regiogt |>
  gt(rowname_col = "Variable") |>
  cols_label(Variable = "") |> 
  opt_stylize(style = 6, color = 'gray')

```

## Chapter 1 - Norwegian small-scale agriculture

### Small-scale farming in Western Norway

- evolution of farming - 1. traditional pluriactivity, without incentives neither other aims than surviving - 2. post-war productivism, which led to increase farm size  - 3. new diversification with added cultural values, this time acknowledged & regulated by public authorities [@daugstadAgricultureUpholderCultural2006]
- Collapse of agricultural holdings since the mid-20th century, from ~200,000 to ~50,000, with a decline of wholly owned holdings and an exponential increase of mainly rented holdings which represent bigger areas with more livestock [@forbordDriversChangeNorwegian2014; SSB]
- small-scale arrangements make particular mutually beneficial relationship between farmer and land-owner in Norway [@forbordDriversChangeNorwegian2014]
- decline of the "traditional" small-scale farming system in Norway with a combined use of livestock and hay-meadows [@wehnAdaptiveBiodiversityManagement2018]
- traditional practices, such as different hay-cutting dates across farms, could enhance heterogeneity between meadows [@wehnAdaptiveBiodiversityManagement2018]
- decrease of livestock leads to biodiversity loss in highly-diversified hay meadows of Western Norway, as it represented the direct economic use of hay & also controlled trampling and fertilisation [@wehnAdaptiveBiodiversityManagement2018]
- Land use history in Western Norway - [@bakkaEarlyFarmingHordaland1971; @hamreLandcoverStructuralChanges2007; @hjelleHesitantHuntersReview2006]
- How grazing systems in Western Norway respond to traditional land use principles [@plieningerTraditionalLanduseNature2006]:
    - Multiple use: farmers usually have a mixed system, with livestock, forest & crop (can rely on some examples from gårdskart)
    - Rotational use: inmark/utmark, also rotations between fields in the same area & between animals
    - Recycling: low nutrient inputs, again inmark/utmark process
    - Low-energy economy: small-scale farming, not much mechanical interference
    - Spatial fuzziness: interactions between different land use structures (e.g. grassland & forest) and processes
- Here I should develop more about heathlands & the utmark system, with literature from Vigdis & Inger & Kari Hjelle
- infield-outfield system provided an exceptionally high level of biodiversity of habitat, species, genetics & landscape [@olssonAgroecosystemsNeolithicTime1991]

### The spectrum traditional - alternative - low-intensive - small-scale farming

Traditional small-scale or low-intensive farming systems represent an alternative to conventional agriculture. According to @plieningerTraditionalLanduseNature2006, traditional farming relies on the following principles: 1. the multiple use of the land, through polyculture and interactions between private, common and public stakeholders; 2. the rotational use of the land, with both spatial and temporal changes; 3. the recycling of outputs into inputs; 4. the energy and resource scarcity of the whole system, including externalities; 5. the spatial fuzziness resulting from intertwined land use structures and processes.

- Traditional agroecosystems, often mixed or agroforestry (+ ref to concrete examples in the South), as learning models for sustainable food production [@altieriEcologicalRoleBiodiversity1999; @altieriLinkingEcologistsTraditional2004]
- Relationship between land use intensity and biodiversity loss not always straightforward - some productive land use can also support relatively high biodiversity [@cunninghamCloseYieldgapSaving2013]
- "Traditional" grazing should not be characterized per se as low-intensity, especially in highly populated areas, though high biodiversity can still be hosted thanks to many nutrient & input gradients at local & regional scales [@plieningerTraditionalLanduseNature2006]
- Low-intensity farmlands are characterized by low nutrient inputs & low output per hectare [@bignalLowIntensityFarmingSystems1996]
- Traditional farming has shaped the landscape through involution [@vosTrendsEuropeanCultural1999], by adapting management practices to natural environment [@bignalLowIntensityFarmingSystems1996], in opposition to conventional agriculture which "replace" existing landscapes thanks to technological advances which give control over natural conditions
- Even in small-scale systems, changes in management with the use of fertilizers and seed mixtures, which can still affect species diversity [@beckmannConventionalLandUse2019]. In our case, only 4 of our infields were without any sort of treatment apart from grazing.

### Cultural landscapes and traditional agriculture

- Categorisation of cultural landscape by the World Heritage Convention [see  @phillipsNatureCulturalLandscapes1998]
- With time, the primary role of agricultural areas, which represented the main labour supplier for food production, has declined at the same time as new demands have raised, such as recreation & nature conservation [@vosTrendsEuropeanCultural1999]
- the concept cultural landscape used to be closely related to agricultural lands, including both infields and outfields, and only more recently that the term expanded to include urban areas. Ministry of Environment still has the tendency to associate traditional/historic farming to cultural landscape [@daugstadAgricultureUpholderCultural2006]

## Chapter 2.1 - Accounting for the climate-landform gradient of the fjord system

### Habitat productivity

(1) Site productivity was as expected a strong factor of variation of soil nutrient cycling [**ref**] and plant functional group diversity [@bakkerHerbivoreImpactGrassland2006; @debelloGrazingEffectsSpecies2007; @lezamaVariationGrazinginducedVegetation2014], but higher heterogeneity amongst outfields was seemingly not related to geographical location (PIV) despite sharp differences in temperature and precipitation between the coast and the moutains [@meteorologiskinstituttNorskKlimaservicesenter2023]. Climate effect could be buffered by the high in-field heterogeneity of outfields [@negronConsequencesIntensiveGrazing2019], with similar mosaic of ecological conditions met at both ends of the gradient through for instance topographic complexity [@graaeStayGoHow2018; @mysterudEffectsDensitySeason2007], grazing [@augustineFeedbacksSoilNutrients2003; @hopcraftHerbivoresResourcesRisks2010] or concurring management practices such as rotational prescribed burning on the coast (PI).

- Climate can also interact with grazing as water availability affects digestible quality of plant biomass [@hopcraftHerbivoresResourcesRisks2010], and sheep foraging patterns in higher elevation are influenced by the weather [@mysterudEffectsDensitySeason2007].
- We did not consider ground-dwelling arthropods, for which temperature can be important driver along elevation gradient [@sandersTemperatureNotProductivity2007]
- Site productivity can for instance alter plant species richness response to grazing even across a shorter gradient [@pakemanLongTermImpacts2019].
- influence depends on plant functional type [@austrheimPlantDiversityPatterns2002] -> e.g. vascular & cryptogams responding differently to elevation and soil nutrient/LOI
- temperature interacted with soil moisture & soil improvement for total herbage mass @negronConsequencesIntensiveGrazing2019
- in savanna, stronger interaction rainfall x primary production when cattle-grazed than abandoned [@augustineFeedbacksSoilNutrients2003]
- environmental variables (site productivity, evolutionary grazing history) more important than grazing variables (consumption) to plant species composition [@milchunasQuantitativeEffectsGrazing1993]
- change in plant species composition & richness under grazing against no grazing more important on high productivity sites [@lezamaVariationGrazinginducedVegetation2014]
- grazing increase plant species richness in high productive sites but decrease in low productive sites, even if number of exclusive species increases in both cases [@bakkerHerbivoreImpactGrassland2006]

### Species distribution

(2) When only considering infields, we did not find any effect of the landscape zone on vascular plant species richness (PII), but the relationships with assemblage and functional trait composition were not as straightforward. If we found signs of potential influence of the regional gradient over plant (PII, PIII) and beetle (PIII) assemblages as well as forage indicator value (PII), there were either contradicted by complementary analyses (PIII) or dependent on the interaction with the livestock type (PII). Even though temperature and precipitation can affect both plant [@reitaluDeterminantsFinescalePlant2014; @turtureanuScaleTaxondependentBiodiversity2014; @zelnikPlantSpeciesDiversity2013] and animal [@dauberLocalVsLandscape2005; @filazzolaEffectsLivestockGrazing2020] diversity and assemblage composition in grazing fields, regional phenomena may have weaker influence over shorter geographical ranges compared with grazing management or edaphic variables [@siefertScaleDependenceVegetationenvironment2012; PIII]. Local weather and topography could still indirectly affect plant species composition [@andersonRainfallSoilsModify2007] by constraining livestock foraging behaviour [@hesterForagingBehaviourSheep1999; @mysterudEffectsDensitySeason2007] or nutrient and water distribution [**ref**], but it was not verified in our survey (PIII).

- No relationship between rainfall, plant biomass & soil available N & P independently of grazing of native ungulates in Tanzania, but combined effect of rain & grazing on species turnover [@andersonRainfallSoilsModify2007]
- floristic composition affected by annual precipitation & mean annual temperature @zelnikPlantSpeciesDiversity2013
- richness of plant functional groups varied to temperature minimum & annual range @turtureanuScaleTaxondependentBiodiversity2014
- variation staphylinids most explained by temperature @dauberLocalVsLandscape2005
- local environment & biogeographic variables accounted for largest fractions of variability in plant species richness @reitaluDeterminantsFinescalePlant2014
- animal diversity & abundance affected by temperature but not by precipitation @filazzolaEffectsLivestockGrazing2020

### Land use

(3) We found on the other hand a clear correlation between the climate-landform gradient and the land cover surrounding infields (PIII), supporting that the agro-ecological landscape matrix in the NBR fjord system is strongly environmentally constrained [@lundbergAustevollChangingCoastal1991; @nesjeFjordsNorwayComplex2009]. However, this change in landscape composition did not affect finer environmental gradients [**ref**] neither dominant plant [@cousinsModellingEffectsLandscape2003; @soderstromPlantsInsectsBirds2001] or beetle [@avironCarabidAssemblagesAgricultural2005; @bataryResponsesGrasslandSpecialist2007; @martelImpactFarmingSystems2019] assemblages (PIII). If the influence of landscape is not always verified compared with local variables [@dauberLandscapeStructureIndicator2003; @jeanneretQuantifyingImpactLandscape2003], other features than composition can be more significant such as connectivity [@concepcionEffectsLandscapeComplexity2008; @cousinsHotspotsAreGone2008; @schweigerQuantifyingImpactEnvironmental2005], heterogeneity [@burelDifferentialResponseSelected2004; @dramstadIntegratingLandscapebasedValues2001; @zulkaSpeciesRichnessDry2014], configuration [@lecoqLandscapeStructureInfluences2023] or complexity [@cloughFieldSizesFuture2020; @gonthierBiodiversityConservationAgriculture2014].

- Likewise, temporal consideration/historical assessments are suitable
- Such spatially-explicit frameworks offer/can support/are suitable for exploring a wide range of strategies/approaches, as for instance the impact of historical connectivity and continuity/land use history [@leprovostLanduseHistoryImpacts2020; @lindborgHistoricalLandscapeConnectivity2004] and temporal continuity [@hamrePlantSpeciesRichness2010; @woodcockHistoricalLocalLandscape2021]

- effect of landscape not always consistent - e.g. @dramstadIntegratingLandscapebasedValues2001 vs @gonthierBiodiversityConservationAgriculture2014
- multidiversity (plant + arthropod) positively affected by landscape heterogeneity [@zulkaSpeciesRichnessDry2014]
- landscape effect depends on organims mobility [@weibullSpeciesCompositionAgroecosystems2003]
- landscape effect may be bigger when considering fields with lower "naturality level", such as fodder crop [@jonsenResponseGeneralistSpecialist1997]
- landscape variability, heterogeneity & pattern did not show any influence on carabid and spider assemblage composition in different habitat types within agricultural landscape [@jeanneretQuantifyingImpactLandscape2003]
- landscape matrix did not affect plant species diversity [@dauberLandscapeStructureIndicator2003]
- landscape intensification & homogenisation affected carabid communities towards smaller, more mobile and ubiquitous species [@burelDifferentialResponseSelected2004]
- landscape features influence on community composition of plants & butterflies differs according to the type of habitat [@weibullSpeciesCompositionAgroecosystems2003]
- landscape effect on butterfly & carabid species richness significant for conventionally managed farms, but not for organic farms [@weibullSpeciesRichnessAgroecosystems2003]

### Field gradient

At finer scale, grazing effect on plant community and richness is likely to vary according to field productivity [@lezamaVariationGrazinginducedVegetation2014; @zulkaSpeciesRichnessDry2014] and soil nutrient distribution [@klimekPlantSpeciesRichness2007a; @siefertScaleDependenceVegetationenvironment2012], controlled by, amongst other, climate [**REF**], topography [@dorroughPlantNeighbourhoodLandscape2007; @klimekPlantSpeciesRichness2007a; @kleinebeckerEffectsGrazingSeasonal2011] and management [@bakkerDoesResourceAvailability2003; @kleinebeckerEffectsGrazingSeasonal2011].

In paper I, we used heath regeneration stages to represent differences in vegetation height, ground cover, humidity and litter layer following small-scale prescribed burning [@barclay-estrupDescriptionInterpretationCyclical1969; @nilsenEarlyStagesCalluna2005].

soil
- edaphic factors are the most likely to explain the most variation in plant community composition [@siefertScaleDependenceVegetationenvironment2012]
- soil properties still explain significant variation of soil fauna abundance independently of geographical location and land use type [@birkhoferGeneralRelationshipsAbiotic2012]
- N fertilisation affect plant species composition [@klimekPlantSpeciesRichness2007a]

## Chapter 2.2 - Characterising grazing management in small-scale grazing systems

### What to expect

- Redefinition small-scale grazing system - key words: low-intensity, rotational, mixed livestock, complementary management

### What we found

- We tested
- type of livestock (PII, PIII)
- stocking density (PIII)
- complementary practices (PI, PIV)

- If both papers suggested that grazing management had an influence on plant species composition, with different vascular plant species composition in sites grazed by cows (PII) and a significant correlation between grazing management and dominant grass communities in infields (PIII), it is difficult to assure that grazing itself is actually the direct driver.
-  First of all, the relationship between dominant grass species and the set of grazing management variables in paper III was supported in the first step by the canonical correlation analysis, but not by the subsequent redundancy analysis.
- Then, in paper II, if a different plant species composition was associated with cow-grazed infields, it does not mean that cows themselves were the driver of change.
- Indeed, we recorded from the farmer interviews (data not available at the time of PII submission) that cow fields were more heavily fertilised than fields grazed by other animals.
- Thus, on outfields which are less intensively managed, role of grazers maybe more prominent
- [PIV findings, with outfields vs infields]
- Habitat productivity is an important element [@milchunasQuantitativeEffectsGrazing1993], with potential interactions with grazers [@lezamaVariationGrazinginducedVegetation2014]
- In paper II, coastal fields grazed by sheep had lower fodder productivity (PII)
- on low-productive coastal heathland, combination of grazing and fire did influence beetle activity even at fine-scale, even if it did not seem to fundamentally modify the community


#### Grazing

Land use intensification
- Belowground multidiversity less affected by land-use intensification or interannual variation [@allanInterannualVariationLanduse2014]
- no effect of N & P on plant species composition in Tanzanian grasslands grazed by native ungulates [@andersonRainfallSoilsModify2007]

Grazing x no grazing
- overall negative impact of grazing on beta-diversity, affecting more strongly highly productive sites [@lezamaVariationGrazinginducedVegetation2014]
- no clear effect of grazing on graminoid cover, independently of site productivity [@lezamaVariationGrazinginducedVegetation2014]
- decrease of plant species richness along with increase of soil available P with ungulate exclusion [@andersonRainfallSoilsModify2007]
- grazing affect abiotic interactions soil x site & x flooding regime [@graceRelationshipSpeciesDensity1999]

Grazing intensity
- grazing intensity affected plant community in 15y experiment upland grassland but sensitivity depended on community type [@pakemanLongTermImpacts2019]
- intensive cattle grazing increased legumes abundance & evenness & decreased grass abundance compared with extensive in 6y grassland experiments [@dumontPlantHerbivoreInteractions2011]
- light to moderate grazing usually most productive, but even heavy grazing can be equally productive depending on the type of grassland [@pattonEffectsGrazingIntensity2007]
- low-intensity sheep grazing in Mediterranean grasslands with higher plant species richness than moderate and high intensity [@skornikEffectGrazingPressure2010]
- different plant species composition under heavy grazing, but not between light & moderate [@skornikEffectGrazingPressure2010]
- no overall *effect of sheep grazing intensity on plant species richness & Shannon in meta-analysis of sheep-grazed grasslands [@scohierHowSheepAffect2012]
- distribution of CSR strategies primarily affected by grazing intensity in Canadian marshes & wet meadows [@teuberLivestockGrazingIntermountain2013]
- light to moderate grazing intensity (0.7-2.4 LSU/ha) affected bite rate but not forage selectivity in cattle-grazed mesotrophic & semi-natural grasslands [@dumontEffectsLivestockBreed2007]
- light to moderate grazing intensity (0.7-2.4 LSU/ha) only very marginally affected plant species richness & cover of functional groups & dominant species in cattle-grazed mesotrophic & semi-natural grasslands [@scimoneEffectsLivestockBreed2007]
- effect of light to moderate grazing intensity (0.7-2.4 LSU/ha) on ground-dwelling arthropod overall not consistent and mostly dependent from location and grassland type [@wallisdevriesEffectsLivestockBreed2007]
- only very marginal effect of grazing intensity on ground beetle community composition & richness in upland grasslands [@pozsgaiGrazingImpactsGround2022]

Mixed vs single grazing
- Belowground multidiversity (bacteria, fungi, nematodes) not affected by mixed cattle-sheep grazing against single, while aboveground & total multidiversity were [@wangDiversifyingLivestockPromotes2019]
- higher total multidiversity & multifunctionality in mixed sheep & cattle grazing [@wangDiversifyingLivestockPromotes2019]
- No effect of mixed-grazing on plant composition, & no difference between cattle and sheep on plant biomass
[@jerrentrupDiverseSwardsMixedgrazing2020]
- no consistent effect of mixed-grazing/single on herbage consumption in experiment [@seitherSwardCompositionGrazer2012]
- No indication of complementarity between sheep & cattle on mixed-grazing [@jerrentrupLittleGrazerSpecies2015]
- mixed grazing increased diversity, productivity & plant community dissimilarity compared with single sheep & cattle grazing in high-diversity steppe, but no clear effects in low-diversity steppe [@liuImpactsGrazingDifferent2015]

Livestock type
- higher N yields in herbage mass in experimental cattle-grazed yards [@seitherSwardCompositionGrazer2012]
- lower plant species richness, Shannon diversity & evenness under sheep grazing compared to cow grazing [@tothLivestockTypeMore2016]
- Lower cover of short-lived & perennial forbs, and legume in sheep-grazed [@tothLivestockTypeMore2016]
- Higher multi-trait functional diversity (Rao’s quadratic entropy) in cattle-grazed [@tothLivestockTypeMore2016]
- no effect of grazer type on plant species richness on experiment [@jerrentrupLittleGrazerSpecies2015]
- higher grass abundance & evenness in sheep grazing compared with cattle after 6y treatment in grassland experiment [@dumontPlantHerbivoreInteractions2011]
- no clear effect livestock type (sheep vs cattle) on six common foraging species [@cuchillohilarioForageSelectivityCattle2018]
- no effect of livestock type (sheep vs cattle) on plant main groups cover in a 7y experiment in *Molinia* grassland [@fraserImpactSwardComposition2011]
-> farm model varies according to the livestock: usually mixed dairy-beef systems on full-time larger farms while sheep grazing on part-time, smaller farm [@asheimPolicyMeasuresPreserve2020]

Seasonal x continuous
- different plant species composition between cattle rotational and continuous grazing [@boavistaEffectsGrazingRegimes2019]
- higher species richness & evenness under cattle rotational grazing [@boavistaEffectsGrazingRegimes2019]
- no demonstrated benefits of rotational grazing compared with continuous grazing in rangeland experimental research [@briskeRotationalGrazingRangelands2008]
- rotational cattle grazing system increased plant diversity, soil nutrient content & cover of N-poor high-elevation & meso-eutrophic species in sub-alpine & alpine meadows [@perottiYearRotationalGrazing2018]
- no difference in beetle, ant & spider species richness but effect on beetle body size & ecological preferences (shade) & spider body size & hunting strategy (web vs runner) between continuous & late (mid-July) grazing in Nordic grasslands [@lenoirEffectsTimingGrazing2010]
- no sign of better biomass recovery at the end of the season under late grazing compared with early grazing in mountain grasslands [@davisEffectsTimingGrazing2014]
- late cattle grazing enhanced fruit production compared with all season in two grasslands [@lennartssonEffectTimingGrassland2012]

Productivity
- different effect of grazing intensity depending on nutrient status of the ecosystem, with plant species richness nutrient-poor habitats more sensitive to increase grazing [@proulxReversalGrazingImpact1998]
- stronger responses of herbage production & plant community structure to grazing intensity in highly productive mesotrophic grasslands compared to more species-rich ones [@isselsteinEffectsLivestockBreed2007]
- grazing effect on moisture preference & leaf-hopper activity-density habitat/productivity dependent in alkaline steppe & meadows [@tormaDifferencesArthropodCommunities2023]
- low-intensity cattle grazing (1 ind/ha) effect on plant diversity & species composition depends on habitat type (dry, meso & wet) in alkali meadows [@torokTraditionalCattleGrazing2014]
- negative effects of abandonment & fertilisation on wet meadow taxonomic diversity & functional evenness enhanced in more productive sites [@janecekEffectsLanduseChanges2013]

Fertilisation
- N redistribution [@augustineFeedbacksSoilNutrients2003]: in managed habitat, N deposition through dung & urine exceeded total N consumption in forage while in bushland, N forage consumed exceeded N deposition
- light availability & heterogeneity may be bigger drivers than N concentration [@bakkerDoesResourceAvailability2003]
- N fertilisation affect plant species composition [@klimekPlantSpeciesRichness2007]
- mites & to lesser extent collembola most abundant in acidic soils with low nitrate concentration [@birkhoferGeneralRelationshipsAbiotic2012]


#### Depends on biodiversity attribute

- 3 primary attributes of biodiversity are composition, structure & function @nossIndicatorsMonitoringBiodiversity1990

species richness x community composition
- in wet Moliniea meadows different drivers plant species richness (soil > climate > topography > management) & composition (elevation > pH > flooding frequency > temp > mowing date > humidity > precipitation > P > N) [@zelnikPlantSpeciesDiversity2013]
- in Mediterranean grasslands, plant species diversity differed between low, moderate & high grazing intensity while community composition only differed in high intensity [@skornikEffectGrazingPressure2010]
- variation partitioning more explanatory for species diversity than for species composition -> can be due to statistical method or actual complexity of community responses compared to diversity [@klimekPlantSpeciesRichness2007]
- landscape elements more influential on community composition of ground & dung beetles than species diversity [@soderstromPlantsInsectsBirds2001]
- contrary to species richness, most community structures (plants, beetles, butterflies) driven along infield tree cover gradient & % arable fields in landscape [@soderstromPlantsInsectsBirds2001]
- Carabidae species diversity responded to sheep & goat grazing intensity while community composition primarily responded to elevation gradient (0-2200 m) in Mediterranean shrubland [@kaltsasGroundBeetlesRespond2013]
- big shift in community composition may have only little effect on richnesss, evenness & diversity [@avolioChangesPlantCommunity2014]
- beetle and spider community composition responded to fertilisation in subalpine meadow but not species richness [@lessard-therrienImpactsManagementIntensification2018]

Diversity vs abundance
- only ground beetle abundance clearly responded to sheep grazing intensity in upland grasslands [@pozsgaiGrazingImpactsGround2022]  
- low grazing intensity decreased Shannon & Simpson diversity but increased abundance & biomass in comparison with 15y abandonment & moderate grazing [@tonelliEffectsProgressiveAbandonment2018]

Diversity indexes (alpha vs beta vs gamma)
- alpha diversity of semi-natural grasslands increased with proportion & diversity of natural & semi-natural habitats in the neighbourhood, while beta & gamma diversity increased with proportion & diversity of non-natural habitats [@janisovaLandscapeEffectsDiversity2014]

Functional vs taxonomic diversity
- functional diversity more temporally stable than taxonomic diversity under increasing grazing intensity, but still affected when intensity high in environments with limiter water availability @carmonaTaxonomicalFunctionalDiversity2012
- grazing intensity directly influenced both taxonomical & functional richness in sub-alpine & alpine grasslands, but not functional dispersion or evenness [@komacFunctionalDiversityGrazing2015]
- effect continuous vs late grazing mostly reflected in functional diversity of arthropods rather than species richness [@lenoirEffectsTimingGrazing2010]
- distribution of CSR strategies primarily affected by grazing intensity in Canadian marshes & wet meadows [@teuberLivestockGrazingIntermountain2013]
- area of historically preserved species-rich grasslands in the landscape affected arthropod species richness but did not filter specific traits [@woodcockHistoricalLocalLandscape2021]
- morphological traits, particularly linked to dispersal, good indicators of species responses to management intensity at both local and landscape scales [@neffCrossscaleEffectsLand2019]
- species & functional diversity highly (+) correlated in alpine Mediterranean grasslands [@catorciEffectsGrazingVs2014]

- species density & biomass in meadows do not respond to the same predictors [@graceRelationshipSpeciesDensity1999]


#### Depends on taxa

Plant vs arthropod
- plant richness more sensitive to local management intensification than invertebrates & vertebrates, while the latter significantly correlated with landscape complexity contrary to the former [@gonthierBiodiversityConservationAgriculture2014]
- no correlation between species richness of ant, wild bee & vascular plant when assessing for influence landscape matrix on grassland diversity [@dauberLandscapeStructureIndicator2003]
- no significant correlation between plant & ground beetle species richness in light cattle & sheep grazed calcareous grasslands [@lyonsImpactsContrastingConservation2017]
- plant & ground beetle community response to grazing management significantly correlated but not strongly enough to be considered as proxy in light cattle & sheep grazed calcareous grasslands [@lyonsImpactsContrastingConservation2017]
- different taxa (butterflies, carabids, plants) preferentially responded to different landscape features [@weibullSpeciesCompositionAgroecosystems2003]
- some common driver of diversity (e.g. vol juniper shrubs for butterflies, bumblebees & dung beetles, or number tree species for plants & dung beetles) and community composition (e.g. % arable fields in landscape for vascular plants & dung beetle, tree cover for vascular plants, dung beetles & ground beetles) [@soderstromPlantsInsectsBirds2001]
- landscape matrix effect NS for plants but had effect on ants through % forest & fallow lands, and on wild bees through % arable lands [@dauberLandscapeStructureIndicator2003]
- plant & spider species richness showed opposite response to land use, nitrogen content & moisture, with spiders favoured by fallows & plants more diverse in meadow & pasture [@bucherBiodiversityLowintensityPastures2016]

Arthropod vs arthropod
- only Coleoptera abundance/richness showed positive to negative responses to grazing against no grazing or grazing intensity increase while Orthoptera, Lepidoptera, Hemiptera & Aranea abundance/richness only showed neutral to positive responses in sheep-grazed grassland meta-analysis [@scohierHowSheepAffect2012]
- both spider & ground-beetle abundance & community composition responded to fertilisation on sub-alpine meadow but ground-beetle community more site-specific than spider [@lessard-therrienImpactsManagementIntensification2018]
- epigeic & ground-dwelling arthropod diversity responded differently to vegetation clipping but both assemblage composition were driven by light incidence & average humidity in sandy mixed-grass prairie [@pratherPlantsRegulateGrassland2019]
- leaf-hopper more sensitive to low-intensive grazing vs no grazing than ground beetle or spider in alkaline meadows & steppe [@tormaDifferencesArthropodCommunities2023]
- Auchenorrhyncha most sensitive taxa to local & landscape management compared with Heteroptera & Orthroptera [@neffCrossscaleEffectsLand2019]

Aboveground vs belowground
- Belowground multidiversity (bacteria, fungi, nematodes) not affected by mixed cattle-sheep grazing against single, while aboveground & total multidiversity were [@wangDiversifyingLivestockPromotes2019]
- belowground diversity does not respond to land use intensity and change the same way as aboveground diversity. As conservative management decisions are taken in regard to aboveground diversity, it may not stimulate, if not even negatively affect belowground biota [@leprovostContrastingResponsesBelowground2021]
- Belowground multidiversity less affected by land-use intensification or interannual variation [@allanInterannualVariationLanduse2014]

Multidiversity
- multidiversity response to increasing land use intensity differs according to taxonomic groups [@allanInterannualVariationLanduse2014]
- only insect abundance showed significant responses to farming intensity & landscape complexity, while overall abundance following the same trends [@gonthierBiodiversityConservationAgriculture2014]

Functional type
- different responses of bryophyte & lichen richness to humus content, & vascular & lichen to micro-relief [@turtureanuScaleTaxondependentBiodiversity2014]
- vascular & cryptogams responding differently to elevation and soil nutrient/LOI [@austrheimPlantDiversityPatterns2002]
- change in plant species composition under rotational cattle grazing not detected when overall community considered but still significant for mesotrophic, oligotrophic & thermic groups in subalpine & alpine meadows [@perottiYearRotationalGrazing2018]
- tall annual & perennial grasses decreased with cattle grazing intensity while annual thistles (chardons) & crucifers increased in Mediterranean meadows [@sternbergVegetationResponseGrazing2000]
- all arthropod feeding guilds positively affected by % historically preserved species rich grassland in landscape either independently or with interaction [@woodcockHistoricalLocalLandscape2021]

## GLOBAL AGRICULTURE & FOOD DEMAND

@rockneyNarrowBrittleBroad2021

@gillerFutureFarmingWho2021
- AIM: review/opinion piece to investigate the interrelations between farms & farming systems globally, beyond production principles
- Trends in farming
  - Two main pathways for increase farm economic size
    - "intensification": when capital investment in technology is used to increase output with only limited physical footprint
    - "expansion": when capital investment in technology is used to largely increase physical farm size
  - "extensification": increase in farm physical size without increase in input or technology, usually to compensate low productivity
- Common patterns
  - Productivity/economic development: decrease yield gap with increase GDP per capita
  - Agriculture dependency/economic development: strong inverse relationship between agricultural employment & labour productivity
  - Fluidity of farming: limitations of fixed, rigid farm unit, when interchange of land is common practice
- Who are the farmers of the future
  - limitations to focus on production principles (agro-ecological, organic, regenerative, "conventional"...) rather than relationships within food system & between agricultural practices
  - poor definition of the "conventional" farming, which represents very diverse realities in different part of the world
  - regionalisation food production -> desirable but needs support of adapted policies

@zabelGlobalAgriculturalLand2014
- AIM: to model future land suitability for crop for current (1981-2010) & future (2071-2100) climatic conditions
- Current: 91% all suitable land already occupied by agriculture -> expansion will require substitution with other land uses
- Future: 
  - suitability improves on 18.7 Mkm^2^ vs declines on 22.2 Mkm^2^
  - more suitable area in the North, e.g. Canada, Russia & China
  - highest loss suitability in Sub-Saharan Africa & Mediterranea

@clarkComparativeAnalysisEnvironmental2017
- AIM: meta-analysis of life cycle assessments comparing agricultural systems in relation to GHG emission, environmental indicators & nutritional units
- Environmental impact alternative production systems
  - organic vs conventional (n=46)
    - land use organic 25-110% >* conventional
    - energy organic 15% <* conventional
    - eutrophication potential 37% organic >* conventional
    - NS GHG or acidification
  - grass-fed vs grain-fed beef (n=7): only land use grass-fed >* grain-fed, NS for others
- Higher agricultural input efficiency in non-ruminant livestock systems consistently associated with lower environmental impacts (included input's own impact)
- Food type: food with low impact for one environmental indicator tend to have low impacts for all indicators

@vandijkMetaanalysisProjectedGlobal2021
- AIM: meta-analysis projection global food consumption 2010-2050
- Total food consumption 2050: +35%-56%
- Total food demand considering climate change uncertainty: +30%-62% (but not significantly different without climate)
- Conclusions balance previsions from FAO, 2009 (70%) & Tilman et al. 2011 (100-110%) which promote technological solutions over agroecological approach

@theinternationalbankforreconstructionanddevelopmentWorldDevelopmentReport2007
- AIM: report on global agriculture development
- In developing countries, shift from extensive grazing to intensive stall-fed husbandry
- Agriculture & aquaculture revolution, increasing protein supply & diversifying diets, but risks of increasing waste pollution & disease outburst due to growing concentrations of animals near urban & peri-urban areas

@hunterAgriculture2050Recalibrating2017
- AIM: new prediction models on crop production to 2050 & environmental impact
- Production increase of 25-70% above current levels may be enough to meet 2050 demand, may should be strictly constrained by limitation of environmental impacts
- CONCLUSION: need to consider both goals of increased production and limitation (if not decrease) of environmental impact & land degradation

@foleySolutionsCultivatedPlanet2011
- AIM: solution on how to solve food production and land degradation dilemma
- Global increase of croplands and pastures by 3% between 1985 and 2005, but not homogeneously across the globe (even decrease in temperate zone)
- Crop production: 62% (mass) to human, 35% to livestock, 3% to bioenergy & others
- Disparity between Global North & South, with only 40% of crop to direct food production in Western countries vs 80% in Asia & Africa
- Careful with the crop-crop-crop strategy, while developing pastures would provide calories, jobs and food security
![](illustrations/Foley.etal2011_WhatAgricultureShouldAimFor_ConceptModel.png)
- Transformation of agriculture should reduce GHG, biodiversity & habitat loss, unsustainable water withdrawals & chemical pollution
- Increasing food production in non-tropical zones may reduce pressure on tropical forests
->	Switch from grain-fed to pasture-fed animals would enhance food availability. Not just about producing more, but how we produce

FAO DATA 2020
- Decrease in land under permanent meadows and pastures during past 20 years, from 3 388 k to 3 183 k (6%), level we had in 1973
- 2001-2020: 33% Asia; 26% Africa; 24% America; 11% Oceania; 5% Europe (177 k)
- 1981-2000: 28% Asia; 26% Africa; 24% America; 14% Oceania; 10% Europe (306 k)
- 1961-1980: Africa 27%; America 24%; Asia 21%; Oceania 16%; Europe 13% (402 k)

@ramankuttyFarmingPlanetGeographic2008
- AIM: modelling global crop & pasture land cover
- For year 2000: 28 millions km2 pastures, compared to 34.4 millions FAO
- Europe (2000): 0.67 million km2 (14.4% cover land area)

@westLeveragePointsImproving2014
- AIM: how to improve global food security & environmental sustainability
- 1961-2009: percentage of calories from crop production consumed as food decreased from 57% to 51%
- Diet gap (human-edible crop calories which do not end up in food system): US 26%, China 17%, Western Europe 11%, Brazil 6% -> changing allocation in these regions would provide enough calories for 2.4 billion people

@cassidyRedefiningAgriculturalYields2013
- AIM: global patterns of crop production & allocation to determine amount of human-consumable calories globally produced
- Feed crop: 24% global crop production (mass), 36% global calorie production & 53% global plant protein production
- Among the 36% for animal feed, 89% is lost -> only 4% of crop-produced calories available to humans in the form of animal product
- To shift feed & other crop to direct human consumption would increase global calories by 70% or feed 4 billion people

@kastnerGlobalChangesDiets2012
- AIM: how changes in consumption drivers are projected to affect future global demand for cropland
- Steady global increase in average availability of food calories per person during recent decades -> rich diet food with higher rates of increase (including animal products), compared to more basic food with slower increase (cereals) or decrease (roots)
- In Northern Europe, total per capita food supply relatively constant.
- At global level, average land area needed to feed a person in 2005 was 2/3 of 1963 value -> food production more area-efficient
- Switch of category which accounts for the largest land use: from cereals (1963 40%; 2005 31%) to animal product (35%; 38%)
- Half of the 30% total cropland requirement increase between 1963 & 2005 is due to growing land demand for animal products
- Population growth as the major driver of growing land demand, but large heterogeneity according to regions (North vs South)

@zabelGlobalImpactsFuture2019
- AIM: to compare how scenarii of cropland expansion (+ 7.3 million km^2^) & intensification (yield gap closing on 10% - 1.5 million km^2^ - of land with highest intensification potential) would influence agricultural markets & biodiversity
- Both scenarii resulted in equal global production gains of 19% more crop yields compared with reference
- Agricultural markets
  - expansion mostly supported by South & Central America (+146%) & Australia & New Zealand (+78%), while EU turns from net-exporter to net-importer & Russia increases imports
  - intensification mostly supported by Sub-Saharan Africa (+78%), India (+68%) & former Soviet Union (+63%), with drop of crop prices
  - country contradicting trends depending on scenarii - i.e. South & Central America in top for crop expansion, but production would decrease in intensification scenario
- Agriculture-biodiversity hotspots
  - expansion pressure in Central & South America, Central Africa & Madagascar, South Africa, Eastern Australia, South-East Asia
  - intensification pressure overall less pronounced, particularly in Latin America, but still pressure in Sub-Saharan Africa, India, Nepal, Myanmar, China
  - intensification pressurise more cropland users compared with other specialists
  - consistent patterns for low agricultural potentials x low endemism richness (cold spots) for both scenarii
  - "hottest hotspots" whichever scenarii were Central & South America, Sub-Saharan Africa & Australia
- TAKE-HOME: 
  - both scenarii increased food production & lower prices but contradicting impacts in some regions depending on the strategy
  - targeted intensification on regions with lower biodiversity would seem more accurate than expanding croplands, but caution towards sustainable intensification
  
@haberlQuantifyingMappingHuman2007
- AIM: to assess global human appropriation of net primary production according to regions & land uses
- Humans appropriated about 24% of global terrestrial net primary production, among which 12.5% harvest, & about 29% of above-ground NPP, among which 20.4% harvest
- Total HANPP = 53% harvest + 40% land-use induced productivity changes + 7% fires
- HANPP cropping (83.5%) > infrastructure (73%) > grazing land (19.4%) > forestry (6.6%) -> agriculture accounts for 78% HANPP
- Potential (486<611) & harvest (41<296) NPP grazing < cropping, but actual (433>397) & remaining (392>101) NPP grazing > cropping
- HANPP countries: Southern Asia (63%) > Eastern & Southeastern Europe (52%) > Northern Africa & Western Asia (42%) > Western Europe (40%) > Eastern Asia (35%) > Southeastern Asia (30%) > Northern America (22%) > Sub-Saharan Africa (18%) > Latin America & Caribbean (16%) > Central Asia & Russian Federation (12%) > Oceania & Australia (11%)

## SUSTAINABLE INTENSIFICATION

@garnettSustainableIntensificationAgriculture2013

@tilmanGlobalFoodDemand2011

@godfrayFoodSecuritySustainable2014

@wezelBlurredBoundariesEcological2015

@tscharntkeGlobalFoodSecurity2012

@matsonAgriculturalIntensificationWill2006

@fischerMindSustainabilityGap2007

@ewersIncreasesAgriculturalYield2009

@bommarcoExploitingEcosystemServices2018
- AIM: perspective on the role of ecosystem services in food security -> **still crop focused**
- Ecological intensification potential: reducing both yield gap (inherent productivity optimisation) & resource use efficiency gap (ouput/input optimisation)
- Underconsidered ecosystem services for food security: soil fertility, pest control, pollination by other pollinators than domestic bees
- Promoting ecosystem services
  - diversifying crop production
  - targeted diversification: e.g. push-pull combination with pest repellent intercropped in maize fields with pest attraction along the borders
- Interlinked targets
  - minimal environmental impact
  - increase resource use efficiency
  - flexibility & resilience (climate change, pest outbreaks)
  - adaptation to local conditions

@bommarcoEcologicalIntensificationHarnessing2013
- AIM: to review ecosystem services supporting or delivered by crop production & propose perspectives on ecological intensification -> **low relevance**
- Concept: safe space where global food demands met while environmental impacts minimised

@egliWinnersLosersNational2018
- AIM: explore spatial optimisation of sustainable intensification
- Same trends of agriculture intensification by 2040 would lead to a decrease of 11% of global biodiversity for a global production gain of 20%
- However, 60% of biodiversity loss projection would be avoided under national optimization scenario, and 88% would be avoided under global optimization scenario
- In global scenario production gains negatively correlated with national economic reliance on agriculture

@prettySustainableIntensificationAgricultural2014
- AIM: review on impact sustainable intensification in both developing & industrial countries
- "Foraging and farming systems across the world are 'overlapping, interdependent, contemporaneous, coequal and complementary' [@sponselFarmingForagingNecessary1989]"
- Agricultural intensification either
  - increasing yields per hectare
  - increasing cropping intensity per unit of land, input or livestock intensity
  - changing land use from low value crops or commodities to those that receive higher market prices or have better nutritional content
- "triple burden"
  - undernutrition = inadequate consumption of calories & proteins
  - malnutrition = inadequate consumption of other important nutrients
  - overnutrition = excessive consumption of calories
-> Future efforts to intensify agriculture should be targeted towards improving nutrition, as paradox of production increase along with burden depending on the region of the world
- "modern" agroecosystems -> high through-flow systems with external fossil fuel inputs & external harvest/leaking outputs
- transition to sustainability -> redirect to internal energy flows at least partially to support other ecosystem functions while avoiding loss of productivity
- Sustainable production systems -> "diverse, synergistic and tailored to their particular social-ecological contexts"
  - use crop varieties & livestock breeds with high ratio productivity to use of externally & internally derived inputs
  - avoid unnecessary use of external inputs
  - harness agro-ecological processes such as nutrient cycling, biological nitrogen fixation, allelopathy, predation & parasitism
  - minimise use of technologies or practices with adverse impacts on environment & human health
  - make productive use of human capital in the form of knowledge & capacity to adapt & innovate & of social capital to resolve common landscape-scale or system-wide problems
  - minimise impacts of system management on externalities (GHG, clean water...)
- Conventional vision of agricultural sustainability implies net reduction of inputs & intensity, though may not be fitted for all contexts -> "a better concept is one that centres on intensification of resources, making better use of existing resources & technologies" -> sustainable intensification
- "no clear conceptual, methodological or practical dividing line between ‘alternative’ and ‘conventional’ practice".
- Results from farm case study of economic success while positive impact on natural capital in the US:
  - all farms emphasized the importance of maintaining and building up natural resource base & maximising use of internal resources
  - all farmers emphasized values of environmental sustainability & importance of closed nutrient cycles
  - crop farms emphasized careful soil management, use of crop rotation & cover crop
  - livestock farms followed management practices not using hormones & antibiotics
  - more farmers participating in non-traditional commodity & direct sales markets
  - farms relied heavily on family members for labour & management
  - challenges & risks centered on rising land & rental values associated with urban development pressure, availability of water & spread of new weed species
-> food outputs increase by multiplicative (combination practices) & additive (diversification activities) ways
- Concrete practices: crop variety improvement; integrated pest management; management-intensive rotational grazing (MIRG) systems; conservation agriculture; agroforestry systems; patch intensification; system of rice intensification.
- Management-intensive rotational grazing systems -> greater temporal & spatial species diversity & improvement animal welfare over traditional (50-75 cattle) to large modern confinement systems (250 cattle)
- Perspectives for concrete implementations
  - both scientific & farmer input into technologies & practices which combine crops & animals with appropriate agroecological & agronomic management
  - creation of novel social infrastructure which both results in flows of information & builds trust amongst individuals & agencies
  - improvement of farmer knowledge & capacity through the use of farmer field schools & communication technologies
  - engagement with private sector to supply goods & services, & development of farmers capacity to add value through their own business development
  - focus on women's educational, microfinance & agricultural technology needs
  - ensuring that microfinance & rural banking is available to farmers' groups
  - ensure public sector support to lever up necessary public goods -> innovative & capable research systems, dense social infrastructure, appropriate economic incentives, legal status for land ownership, improved access to markets
  
@milderAssessmentMultifunctionalityAgroecological2012
- AIM: to review agroecological intensification approaches (conservation agriculture, holistic grazing management, organic agriculture, precision agriculture, system of rice intensification) & their impact on ecosystem services
- Nature gap = "the deficit in the provision of ecosystem services and other conservation values between any given farming system and a system in the same environment and with the same level of agricultural outputs that is optimally managed for ecosystem co-benefits"
- All systems encourage farmer decision-making in response to monitoring of system conditions & responses -> no strictly followed rules, much open to interpretation -> extend heterogeneity & variability
- Ecosystem services x yield
  - conservation agriculture & holistic grazing management -> mainly improvement of ecosystem service provision, but contradicting regarding yield
  - organic agriculture -> no main trend, but no record of yield decrease with ecosystem services increase
  - precision agriculture -> almost always increase yield, never decrease yield & ecosystem services, but mostly neutral than gain in ecosystem services
  - system rice intensification -> mainly win-win
- Data availability issue: except for certified organic farming, very hard to evaluate the extent of adoption of these practices, and thus to assess their effect
- "At present there is not an adequate empirical basis to develop quantitative estimates of the aggregate contribution of AEI to food production or specific ecosystem benefits at a global scale."
- TAKE-HOME: research gap between, on one hand, farm-scale research investigating local effects of AEI but with poor appreciation of aggregate effects or scalability, and on the other hand global research assessing aggregate targets & alternative pathways to meet them but with little consideration of role of AEI

@rockstromSustainableIntensificationAgriculture2017
- AIM: to propose a paradigm for sustainable intensification to be defined & translated into operational framework for agricultural development
- Objective: to shift from paradigm with productivity first & sustainability as a cover up for reduction environmental impacts, to paradigm where sustainability makes the core strategy for agricultural development
- Sustainable intensification according to proposed paradigm: hunger reduction through biodiversity conservation that secures ecological functions in agricultural landscapes -> use of both land-sparing & land-sharing approaches across local & regional scales
-> new definition of sustainable intensification from socio-ecological criteria = "adopting practices along the entire value chain of the global food system that meet rising needs for nutritious and healthy food through practices that build socio-ecological resilience and enhance natural capital within the safe operating space of the Earth system."
- long-term SIA is not only about local farm productivity through practices but equally consider safeguarding ecological functions across scale and enhancing resilience against rising frequency &/or intensity of shocks and stresses from global changes
-> "strategic land-use planning to maintain and improve interacting stocks & flows [...] across landscape mosaics [...] so that multi-functionality of the whole landscape is manageable across scales."
- three-step approach
  - 1. as resource efficient as possible by combining locally relevant breeds & crops with/without genetic improvement with minimum inputs & close nutrient, carbon & water cycles
  - 2. landscape-scale resilience by sustaining ecosystem functions & services
  - 3. connect thinking, planning & practice across scales to apprehend ecological interactions in Anthropocene
- TAKE-HOME: 
  - livelihood-centered paradigm for sustainable intensification entails trans-disciplinarity & solution-oriented knowledge generation combining academic & practical knowledge through co-design & co-development of research
  - "grand experiments" with transdisciplinary collaboration to pilot sustainable intensification at regional/basin scale, as large R&D investments, to pool experience, explore synergies and trade-offs


## GLOBAL LIVESTOCK TRENDS

@piipponenGlobalTrendsGrassland2022
- AIM: to estimate the global trends of livestock carrying capacity over 2001-2015 period
- Median AGB & CC: Norway overall amongst lowest range (<5 animal unit/km^2^/y)
- Global trends CC: NS (58% total area) > negative (27%) > positive (15%) -> most drastic decrease in Europe
- Stocking density -> regionally medium (20%-65%)-overstocked (>65%) compared with carrying capacity, but not always visible when flattened on the whole country area
- TAKE-HOME:
  - 27% global grassland area with declining carrying capacity, mostly concentrated in Europe
  - high stocking density in Western Norway compared with carrying capacity

@fetzelSeasonalityConstraintsLivestock2017
- AIM: to globally estimate the limiting effect of seasonality on grazing intensity in natural grasslands
- Global observed grazing intensity of total area (GIobs)
  - <15% on 79% of total area: <2% on 36%; <5% on 56%; <10% on 71%
  - high prevailing in arid & semi-arid regions where can >50%
- Grazing intensity limited by seasonality (GIseason)
  - >10% on ~33% & >15% on 23% all grazing lands
  - >10% prevailing in Latin America & Sub-Saharan Africa, where GIobs often <2%
- Difference GIobs & GIseason
  - GIobs > GIseason ~61% total global natural grassland: East & Southeastern Europe, Northern Africa, Western Asia, Southern Asia -> increase socio-economic costs for other feeding sources

## FOOD SECURITY & LOCAL FOOD SYSTEMS

Conventional and traditional agricultures rely on fundamentally different approaches of natural resources management [@bignalLowIntensityFarmingSystems1996; @vosTrendsEuropeanCultural1999]. Conventional farming is driven by objectives of performance and efficiency on the short-term. It aims to maximise the production by overcoming environmental constraints through the use of machinery and agrochemistry, resulting in homogenisation of landscapes and practices [@jongmanHomogenisationFragmentationEuropean2002]. On the other hand, traditional small-scale farming has developed to adapt to the local environment, with diversified practices and limitation of inputs. This strategy prioritises long term preservation of the natural capital over immediate production and enhances both the heterogeneity and the resilience of the agroecosystem [@gardnerAgriculturalResiliencePerspectives2019; @menconiRevisitingGlobalFood2022].

@gliessmanAgroecologyAgroecosystems2004

  - Relationship between land use intensity and biodiversity loss not always straightforward - some productive land use can also support relatively high biodiversity
  - impact should not be only assessed by area, but through the whole production system
- Adapt to landscape
  - Biodiversity value and production potential vary across the globe
  - Different land use history also affect potential outcomes
    - heavily transformed land (e.g. cereal plain in Australia) will be hard to change
    - agroforestry with cacao and coffee which ressemble native habitats
  - Trade-offs depend on the type of agro-ecological systems -> no global magical solution
- Smallholdings: intensification would be harmful not only for biodiversity but also for local population
- TAKE-HOME: 
  - strategy to close the yield gaps should be rooted within people's cultural values and be adapted to local environment and historical land use
  - "techniques for improved yield are only appropriate if they can be implemented in the smallholder context and avoid homogenisation of the diverse landscape"

@menconiRevisitingGlobalFood2022
- AIM: use Food Self-Sufficiency Index to assess food system resilience at local scale for different communities
- Index created from ecological footprint (consumption of a community) and biocapacity indices (production potential of an area) -> ecological balance between production and consumption in an area
- 4 steps
  - Community - evaluation of food demand of the local community
  - Land - calculation of agro-climatic maps of the study area
  - Crops - evaluation of crop suitability

  - involving local community, participatory approach
  - increasing agrobiodiversity & heterogeneity to improve resilience in changing environment

@herreroSmartInvestmentsSustainable2010

@douwevanderploegPeasantriesTwentyfirstCentury2010
- AIM: to comment and investigate the trend of peasantry re-emergence and discuss continuities and disruptions between old and modern peasantry
- Drawback of the current conventional system: not only it excluded farmers from the get go, but in the end it also destroys farmers who decided to follow the trend and convert themselves
- Evolution of peasantry through time with a good share of transformation -> high adaptability capacity, can take very diverse forms
- From land to ecological capital
  - Conventional: Transformation farming into conversion of commodities, maybe from somewhere else, to other commodities, which can go somewhere else
  - "The more farming is grounded on ecological capital, the lower the monetary coasts of production will be"
  - Continuity but disruption in the way that now it is a conscious choice, while before it was self-evident, no other way to go
  - Centrality of ecological capital both requires and contributes to relative autonomy which develops local network and knowledge
- From subsistence to self-provisioning
  - self-provisioning refers to the necessary resources to the unit of production, while subsistence refers to the unit of consumption
  - self-provisioning sustains autonomy while enlargement tighten dependency within production processes

- From partial integration to actively constructed distantiation

# AGRICULTURE, BIODIVERSITY, HABITAT

## CHARACTERISATION AGRICULTURE

@sumbergWhatConventionalAgriculture2022
- AIM: to discuss the meaning and use of the adjective "conventional" when characterising agriculture
- three observed uses of the word "conventional"
  - in experiment/analytical context, as reference or control against alternative practices
  - in conceptualisation of alternative agricultural practices, with inherent assumptions (destructive, mechanised, large-scale, controlled by corporations...)
  - in promotion of new forms of agriculture in the modern sense, in that case conventional will be old-fashioned and conservative
- evolution of meaning through time
  - 50s-60s - reference to everyday agriculture, ordinary, common place
  - 70s-80s - increased use to characterise practices to be compared to organic farming
  - afterwards, increasing use of conventional as opposed to specific alternative systems without proper definition
- "The recognition of the need for local adaptation is both important and pragmatic, but it complicates any attempt to investigate the performance or potential advantages of these alternatives"
- Take-home message: not denying current challenges for agriculture or the need for characterising farming practices, but warning to use inconsiderately the dichotomy conventional-alternative (parallel with modern-traditional), while the reality is a complex gradient that depends on local environmental conditions, historical management...
- MISSING POINT ACCORDING TO ME - how about education? At least at the national scale (and I argue now transnational, with globalisation and international market), there are norms, practices promoted by institutions and organisms who trained the future farmers, and also agriculture lobbies (in opposite with the 'old days' where it was direct knowledge transmission from expert).

## AGRICULTURE & BIODIVERSITY

@seppeltHarmonizingBiodiversityConservation2016

@chappellFoodSecurityBiodiversity2011
- AIM: literature review on relationships between food insecurity & biodiversity loss, with an emphasis on comparing agricultural methods
- Conventional vs alternative
  - Conventional practices
    - industrial model of increased production centralisation/consolidation
    - functional separation
    - claims of economic efficiency
    - attempts to control & manage nature as commodity
  - Alternative
    - holistic & multifunctional system integrating natural ecological processes
    - high levels of recycling
    - fundamental interconnections between agriculture, human culture & larger social issues in the rest of the food system
    - proposed definition relies on intention rather than methodology = "range of management and technological options used to reduce costs, protect health & the environment, & enhance biological interactions & natural processes" from the US National Research Council
- Alternative systems shown to be more energy efficient than conventional systems
- Counter-argument against land sparing: no clear evidence that more land is necessary to produce sufficient yields to adequately feed the world
- "There is evidence to support the proposition that alternative agricultural methods can provide enough food, on the global scale, to provide a comparable level of food security as would conventional agriculture"
- Alternative more based on synergy biodiversity/production vs conventional trade-off
- "The obvious alternative to complete global redistribution of food is to enhance self-sufficiency on a regional & sub-regional basis"
- Food security framework Rocha's Five A's:
  - Availability refers to the sufficiency of a food supply to meet people's need
  - Accessibility refers to people's economic & physical ability to acquire food
  - Acceptability addresses the cultural and nutritional suitability of the available food
  - Appropriateness evaluates the ecological sustainability & the safety of a food supply
  - Agency is the "right to knowledge and knowledge of rights"
  -> up to now disproportionate efforts towards availability while not much on the rest

- AIM: perspective on how to reduce by half nitrogen losses in Europe while keeping food production & feed import levels
- Past trends 1961-2013: increase population (428 to 540 millions) + protein consumption (4.9 to 5.7 kgN/cap/y) + share animal proteins but fish (35% to 55%) while decrease agricultural land
- Characteristics European agro-food system
  - heavily dependent on synthetic N fertiliser inputs
  - large burden of livestock metabolism in overall agricultural N cycle with consumption 75% European crop protein production + 2.7 million TgN/y in imported feed
  - Norway: particularly high fraction of imported feed in livestock nutrition (40-60%) compared with European average (19%)
- N losses 1961-2015: from 9.5 to 11.3 TgN/y
- Agro-ecological scenario based on 3 levers
  (1) changing diet + human excreta recycling: 5 kgN/cap/y made of 45% cereal + 15% fresh fruit & vegetables + 10% grain legumes + 30% animal
  (2) agro-ecological practices avoiding N fertiliser: no change in land cover but implementation crop rotation alternating vegetables, cereals & grain legumes
  (3) reconnecting livestock farming to cropping systems -> back to infield-outfield strategy, making livestock density as only lever of intensification through manure application

@flynnLossFunctionalDiversity2009
- AIM: meta-analysis on the impact of agricultural intensification on functional diversity on different temperate & tropical environments
- 4 scenarii
  - Low functional redundancy - FD decline due to species decline
  - High functional redundancy - FD stable despite decline of species
  - Functionally redundant species lost first - FD decline more slowly than richness, system becomes low redundancy
  - Functionally unique species lost first - FD declines faster than richness, system greatly affected even if only a few species lost
- FD & richness trends
  - both FD & richness of mammals & birds decreased with intensification
  - no pattern for plants
- Expected FD pattern compared to a random assemblage from local species pool
  - for birds & mammals, agricultural and semi-natural landscapes more likely to have lower than expected FD compared with natural landscapes
  - overall studies, natural landscapes more likely to have higher than expected FD
  - no strong trends for plants
- patterns of lost functional traits under intensification
  - birds: body size, food type & foraging habitat - large predators more affected
  - mammals: agricultural areas lacked species with small litter size & some specialists (fish, fruit, seed, nuts)
  - plants: height most important trait (large plants affected)

@beckmannConventionalLandUse2019
- AIM: meta-analysis on the effect intensification on both productivity and species richness for different land uses (forestry, crops, green fodder)
![From Beckmann et al. (2019) - Land use intensity classes](illustrations/Beckmann.etal2019_IntensityTable.png)
- All land use types (forestry, crops, green fodder) considered, intensification within low-intensity systems would not affect yield and species richness (all taxa), but stepping up to medium intensity would expose to species richness loss (-7.7% [-13.7, -1.3]) without substantial yield increase (+6% [-5, +18.3])
- Still all land use types considered: the most impactful intensification was within medium-intensity systems for both yield increase (+84.9% [+65.8, +106.1]) and species richness loss (-22.9% [-28.1, -17.4]) -> but careful, low replication level for meta-analysis (19 & 29 respectively)
- In general for green fodder systems, species richness significantly decrease under intensification (-12.4% [-21.8, -1.9]) & yield increased but not significantly (+14.2 [-5.6, +38.2]). Invertebrates particularly impacted in green fodder compared with other land uses
- land use history, taxonomic group and climatic zone covariates explained significant proportion of heterogeneity

## NORWEGIAN AGRICULTURE

@asheimPolicyMeasuresPreserve2020
- AIM: to model scenario of agricultural policies/practices on Norwegian small-scale sheep & mixed dairy systems
- Already existing subsidies: 
  - Area and cultural landscape support (ACL): non-targeted, only few disapproved practices (e.g. removal pond, stone fences, pesticides on edges...) leading to reduced support -> overall criticised for lack of characterisation of the environmental criteria
  - Husbandry animal support scheme (HAS): no environmental criteria
  - Grazing animal scheme (GS): either support for grazing animal or grazing on outfield area (not both)

  - Axis 1: (-) long-term management intensity & production capacity 1865 vs (+) canopy height -> gradient intensively managed land to semi-natural & woodlands
  - Axis 2: (-) wire fence vs (+) agricultural use -> gradient boundary to open land used for agriculture

  - (+)* predictors: canopy height & continuity

  - (+)* correlated with habitat specificity & gamma diversity
  - (-)* predictors: long-term management intensity & production capacity 1865

- AIM: palynology analysis to determine the period of first forest clearances by humans & subsequent development of heathlands in Western Norway
- Deforestation process lasted for at least 3600y (4000-400 BC) with 3 pronounced clearance periods: Mesolithic/Early Neolithic transition (4000-3600 BC), Middle Neolithic II/Early Late Neolithic transition (2500-2200 BC) & Late Neolithic to Bronze Age period II (1900-1400 BC)

@hetlandPluriactivityStrategyEmployment1986
- AIM: characterise pluriactivity as Norwegian farmer lifestyle and its evolution
- Pluriactivity as "traditional employment adaptation in rural Norway" which shifted from "fishermen farmers" to "white collar farmers" -> at first politics thought this traditional way of living was obsolete and would disappear with modernity, but more recently they changed their minds and are rather thinking of how to stimulate this pluriactivity
- Def pluriactivity = "the diversification of activities carried out by one household on and off the holding in order to secure the household's economy and welfare."
- Evolution
  - before WWII - nearly all farmers pluriactive, including fishing & forestry
  - after WWII - incentives towards "family farms" (without activity off the farm), supported by agricultural policies, but still 2/3 farms pluriactive -> particularly true for our study area with ~75% pluriactive farms
  - However pluriactive farms do not decline more rapidly than family farms, as latter drop from 39% in 1949 to 31% in 1979
- Typology of various forms of pluriactivity & trends 1969-1979
  - *Family* farms without activity outside the farm, but which include forestry, fur farming & farm tourism as long as it is on the same holding -> slight decrease from 33% to 31%
  - *Traditional division* of labour when husband works off the farm and wife at home, responsible of farm work when alone -> strong decrease from 37% to 26%
  - *Complex division* of labour when both spouses employed off the farm & both share in farm work -> strong increase from 4% to 15%
  - *Modern division* of labour when wife works off the farm & husband at home with farm responsibility -> slight increase from 1% to 3%
  - *Single* farmers working both on and off the farm -> relatively stable from 7% to 8%
  - Farmers with *pension* -> stable from 17% to 17%
- Policy support towards pluriactivity to tackle overproduction, unemployment & marginal areas depletion
  - 57% percent all farms provide less than one annual work unit -> defined as pluriactive by the State Bank of Agriculture
  - in 1980, only 6.3% of the farms which received subsidies for loans & grant-in-aid were pluriactive
- Change of pluriactive model during investment phase
  - traditional from 63% to 36%
  - complex from 29% to 10%
  - modern from 9% to 26%
  - family from - to 28%
- Historical evolution of pluriactivity over 3 overlapping periods
  - *subsistence economy* - main motive to secure household's economy & welfare
  - *commercialization and specialization* - specialization risks reduced by technology & welfare payments, & many farmers work off the farm to secure investments in farming
  - *social foothold* - focus on social values connected to farms. Many farmers with full-time work off the farm, & investments not towards farm activity but rather property & place to live
-> from agriculture as central to decide which activities were possible off the farm to the other way around

@dramstadTenancyNorwegianAgriculture2010
- AIM: to analyse trends of agricultural tenancy in Norway from 1999 to 2003
- Average farm size in 1949 ~4.8 ha
- Issues to explore:
  - the extent of tenancy in different regions and how this changes
  - trends in the number of tenancies farmers manage
  - whether tenancy acts as an alternative to abandonment
  - whether landscapes of particular cultural, tourist or ecological significance are being extensively managed via tenancy
- Changes in agriculture from 1999 to 2003
  - number farmers: from 70,740 to 58,231 -> ~18% decline
  - total agricultural area: from 1,038,246 ha to 1,040,385 ha -> ~2000 ha increase
  - average farm size: from 14.7 ha to 17.9 ha -> ~18% increase, smallest change in Hordaland
  - decrease (-45%) in the amount of area managed by smaller farms (<5 ha)
  - increase (+50%) in the amount of area managed by larger farms (>50 ha)
- Occurrence of tenancy
  - from 53.9% to 58.3% farmers who applied for subsidies who rented at least partially -> +7.5%
  - from 46.1% to 38.2% farmers who only manage the land they own -> -17%
  -> decline of traditional owner occupancy as management method in Norway
  - increase of average number of tenancies, maximum number of tenancies per farmer & average area of rented land per farmer -> increase complexity of management arrangements
  - decrease of owner-occupier across all Norway -> more drastic for municipalities which had originally high number and almost negligible for municipalities with the lowest 1999 number (-> sort of low plateau?)
  - areas in orange in 1999 (20-35% OO) likely to have moved to red (0-20% OO)
  - Western Norway (our study area) relatively preserved compared to the rest of the country
  - Most municipalities in Nordhordland with ~50% of tenancy, but with generally low number of tenancies per farmer. Overall areas with most tenancies on the coast, as well as Modalen
- Take-home: 
  - tenancy common & widely used in Norway. represents a large proportion of total agricultural area
  - farmer "survival" strategies
