@daugstadAgricultureUpholderCultural2006
- AIM: exploring interactions between agriculture and cultural heritage in Norway by analyzing explicit and implicit value appreciations
- dilemma as agriculture both a threat & a caretaker of cultural heritage depending on the practices & the environment
- knowledge linking agriculture & cultural heritage mainly related to the multifunctionality concept, either from external perspective (e.g. tourism) or from internal perspective (e.g. farmers)
  - outsiders will be attached to the aesthetics of the old traditional landscape
  - insiders will tend towards productivity and "active" management
- Main concepts explored come from:
  - "Commodification" of cultural heritage = "extension of the commodity form to goods and services that were not previously commodified" (e.g. tourism industry developed around agriculture)
  - authenticity, which can be defined as "being actually and precisely what is claimed", thus opposed to commodification
- chosen concepts: cultural heritage, active agriculture, added value
  - Cultural heritage - individual locality to which there is a historical or prehistoric dimension, event, belief or tradition, with cultural environment being larger contexts of cultural heritage sties representing time-depth or functional relations in the landscape [ref to Miljøverndepartementet]
  - Active farming in relation with cultural heritage (positive/negative) - no clear or obvious difference between active & passive farming
  - Added value in relation to the contribution cultural heritage provide to human, whether monetary or not
- Cultural landscape in Nordic context
  - term has been used as synonymously for agriculturally influenced landscape, especially for traditional/historical agriculture when coming from the Ministry of Environment
  - Ministry Environment, Directorate Cultural Heritage, Directorate Nature Management - cultural heritage sites & environments as expressions of our common memory that communicate knowledge about human life, activity and capacity through time -> help understand relationship between past & present, nature & man, and different cultures
  - Documents from agricultural sector - concept only recently used, focusing on areas of agricultural use associating the practice, the buildings & other cultural elements
  - Norwegian farmers' union - states as major aim to "secure agriculture and maintain rural areas' economic, social and cultural interests".
  - OECD relates to multifunctional as the fact that agriculture may be shaping the landscape & creating environmental goods & contributing to socio-economic sustainability in rural areas
- Active agriculture & cultural heritage
  - Directorate for cultural heritage - "If the dominant cultural heritage values are to be maintained, this requires a sustainable agriculture capable of running, managing, & maintaining values. At the same time this practice must not destroy or diminish the cultural heritage values." -> protection through use
  - Agricultural sector - "living" agriculture as argument for agriculture based on food & fibre production
  - Norwegian farmers' union - farmer as supporter of cultural values
  - Norwegian Smallholders' association - more focus on social degradation of rural areas - no mention of cultural heritage per se, but positive effects on settlement, employment & cultural landscapes as arguments towards small-scale farming
- Added value
  - From environmental sector - cultural heritage as a resource to be used, especially for local communities not only for economic value but also for knowledge, historical insight & sustainable development
  - From agricultural sector - economic potential of cultural heritage seen to add legitimacy for economic sector & lifestyle
- Changing perspectives & policies: change in agricultural policies towards farmer as independent entrepreneur in post-productivist context -> diversification of agriculture in activities beyond conventional farming

@forbordDriversChangeNorwegian2014
- AIM: to investigate what have been the changes of farmland control in Norway for the past 50 years
- Collapse of agricultural holdings [statNorwaySSB], from ~200,000 in 1959 to ~50,000 50 years after, while number of properties stable -> increase size of working farms & shift from owner occupation to renting
- post-WWII social contract emphasized productivity, self-sufficiency, efficiency & maintaining farmer income ~ urban worker
- notion of "ownership" in agricultural land management - "land tenure governs the relationship between people and the environment by setting restrictions and rights on physical interaction and consequently defining permissible cultural engagement"
- prior to 1900s, ownership/rental relationship heavily in favour of land owner, but in recent decades return of land leasing but with more complex network of stakeholders
- Comparative areas: Eastern Norway (cereal), Central-West (intensive livestock), Western Norway (extensive livestock, with fruit/berry production)
- Agricultural policy & legal & economic instruments
  - legal vs economic: direct impact of legal with transfer of land rights through state, while economic influences production by defining desirable land use options
  - policy encouraging deregulation & market-oriented decisions started in the 1990s, with cut of subsidies for grain (became cheaper food for livestock), subsequent increase of maximum legal size of animal production systems
  - Concession Act - obligation of residency on property 5 years after take-over & regulation purchase by legal persons
- Change in farmland control in Norway (SSB)
  - wholly owned holdings from ~170,000 (87%) in 1959 to ~16,000 (35%) in 2010
  - mainly owned from ~10,000 (5%) in 1959 to ~16,000 (35%) in 2010
  - mainly rented from ~2500 (1%) in 1959 to ~10,000 (23%) in 2010 -> exponential increase, with largest total farm size & average number livestock
  - wholly rented from ~14,000 (7%) in 1959 to ~3,700 (8%) in 2010
- Ownership & renting from farmer perspective
  - cheap rent compared to buying cost -> rental agreement generally mutually beneficial
  - uncertainty linked to the lacking perspectives of succession
  - however whole-rent not encouraging for young farmers -> e.g. 10 years engagement without ownership perspective is not interesting
  - increase of rented farms leads to land fragmentation -> farmers dealing with pieces of land scattered, which increase travel time & cost
- Take-home: three main factors affecting farmland control in Norway are techno-economic (e.g. machinery), agricultural policies (legislation, economic instruments) & social norms (e.g. managing isolated land for relatives)

@fjellstadPatternsChangeTwo1999
- AIM: to compare trends between an intensively cultivated area & a traditional mountain-farm landscape during second half of 20th century to illustrate opposed drivers intensification vs abandonment
- Difference in Norway compared with Europe - environmental constraints (topography & climate) technically limiting intensification + economic & social incentives from regional politics to maintain marginal farming -> not so much replacement, but co-existence of small-scale "traditional" farming systems with mechanised, high-input agriculture

- National statistics
  - Decline of both number of agricultural holdings (61%) & labour input (70%) from 1949 to 1995
  - Decline of small holdings (<10 ha) representing 90% of holdings in 1949 against 53% in 1995 -> -41%
  - Increase of larger holdings (>20 ha) representing 2% in 1949 against 16% in 1995 -> +87.5%
  - Decline of total agricultural area by 8% since 1939, but heterogeneous depending of regions & management type
    - "intensive" - collapse of permanent grassland & superficially cultivated land by 91% and meadows & pastures by 80% while surface grain & oil seeds tripled from 1939 to 1989
    - "traditional" - meadows & pastures ~stable but decline of permanent grassland & superficially cultivated land
- Land cover between 1953 and 1992
  - "intensive" - increase cultivated land & decrease pasture -> intensification
  - "traditional" - increase deciduous tree & decrease pasture -> encroachment
  - landscape heterogeneity: "traditional" 1955 ~ "traditional" 1993 > "intensive" 1953 > "intensive" 1992
- Norway vs Europe
  - Less marked decline of agricultural land in Norway (5%) compared with Europe (8%) between 1965 & 1983
  - common trends with increased mechanisation, decline in labour input, reductions in numbers of holdings & increasing size of individual farms, though average farm size still stay quite small in Norway (13 ha in 1996) compared with other countries
- Take-home: landscape "polarisation" with two extremes being large-scale intensively managed & homogeneous open landscapes on one side & small-scale, heterogeneous wooded agricultural landscapes on the other side

  - 2. Maintaining factors
    - livestock grazing - 4 components as type of livestock, single/mixed grazing, grazing pressure, time of the year/duration grazing periods

    - cultivation - many components such as crop species, seed-bed preparation, tilling, seeding, fertilizer/manure, draining, harvest, cropping systems...

	  - industrial production landscapes

## ECOLOGICAL TRAITS

@loreauBiodiversitySpatialInsurance2003
- AIM: to explore hypothesis of spatial insurance heterogeneous landscape for ecosystem functioning by relying on metacommunity model with explicit resource & dispersal dynamics
- Local vs regional div
  - no dispersion
    - local div: no coexistence as only most competitive species survive
    - regional div: high as different species persist in different communities
  - up to intermediate dispersion level 
    - local div: (+) from source-sink community effects
    - regional div: temporary drop, as specialists of environmental extremes with longest local dominance outcompete other species at low dispersal, before new increase with dispersal, as intermediate species better adapted to average environmental conditions across metacommunity
  - up to coexistence all species: shifts in dominance reflect how traits match environmental conditions
  - high dispersion: (-) both local & regional div as intermediate species becomes best competitor at metacommunity scale
- Productivity
  - temporal mean: hump-shaped with peak at intermediate dispersion -> (+) correlation between average productivity & local species diversity
  - temporal variability: reversed hum-shaped with lowest at intermediate dispersion & highest at no dispersion -> (-) correlation between coefficient variation productivity & local species diversity
  - lower variability of high dispersal dominant intermediate species compared with lower dispersal dominant specialist species -> higher mean & lower variability productivity in highly connected metacommunity compared with poorly connected despite min local species richness for both
- TAKE-HOME:
  - "variations in dispersal rate generate strongly nonlinear, broadly correlated variations in local species diversity, average productivity & the coefficient of variation of productivity"
  - "spatial averaging by the intermediate-type species tends to dominate the landscape at high dispersal rates and functional compensations between species are made possible by the maintenance of species diversity"
  - "The spatial insurance effects of species diversity are highest at the intermediate dispersal rates that maximize local diversity"

@liFunctionalGroupDominance2016

@graceFactorsControllingSpecies1999
- AIM: to conceptualize general rules based on empirical evidence on control of species density in herbaceous plant communities
- 1) Underlying unimodal relationship between species density & total community biomass
  - increasing phase above some minimum habitat conditions required to support life
  - decreasing phase in highly productive habitats accumulating large amounts of biomass
- 2) Community biomass as relatively weak predictor of variations in species density
  - species density influenced by multiple additional variables
  - high amounts of community biomass preclude high species densities
- 3) Importance of disturbance & underlying gradients
- Conceptual model
  - Species density in a fixed space determined by recruitment (germination, vegetative) & extinction (natural mortality, disturbance, competitive exclusion, disease) balance
  - Recruitment depends on existing biomass of the species & others from a species pool adapted to environmental conditions
  - Extinction: complexity disturbance regimes & effects
  - Recruitment & extinction occur through activities of both living & dead plant material & subsequent habitat functioning
  - Growth rate expected to be function of environmental conditions & amount & type of biomass already present
  - Potential for differential effects of environmental gradients on biomass vs effects on species density

@vanzuijlenDecomposabilityLichensBryophytes2020
- AIM: to investigate the decomposability of bryophytes & lichens at species & community level along elevation gradient (1120-1600 masl)

@hartleyTemperatureEffectsCarbon2021
- AIM: global survey to investigate the interaction between temperature & soil texture on soil C stabilisation
- C storage in fine-textured soils with greater stabilisation capacities was less affected by temperature than when in coarse-textured soil (1.2 per 10C vs 1.9) -> negative relationship between clay content & effect of temperature on C storage
- C stored in high-latitude soils with limited capacities for stabilising OM likely to be most vulnerable to impacts of climate change

@dungaitSoilOrganicMatter2012
- AIM: review on how advances in quantitative analytical techniques have redefined the new understanding of SOM dynamics
- Main controlling decomposition factors
  - substrate quality, which includes
    - supply organic molecules for both catabolis (energy conversion) & anabolic (biosynthetic) metabolism
    - supply other nutrient elements to decomposer organisms
    - extent to which properties of substrate retard its exploitation (hydrophobia, enzyme inhibitors)
  - organisms (including enzymatic activity)
  - environment
    - temperature: "although it is well established that biological processes which drive decomposition will be more rapid at greater temperatures, being able to assign a thermal coefficient to decomposition & nutrient mineralisation has proved remarkably difficult"
    - "there is a practical difficulty of disentangling the effects on the decomposer communities of relative depletion of the most accessible components of the SOM from the direct effects of temperature on the metabolism of soil micro-organisms"
- Preservation mechanisms
  - physical protection - aggregates & organo-mineral complexes (e.g. with clay) -> adsorption affinity to mineral exceeds that of enzyme active site
  - regulation microbial activity by substrate supply - "Trigger molecule hypothesis"

@schmidtPersistenceSoilOrganic2011
- AIM: review recent findings on SOM cycling & implication of abiotic & biotic factors - *classic*
- Assumptions & verifications
  - Molecular structure does not control long-term decomposition of SOM
    - assumption: long-term decomposition rate depends on molecular structure of biomass as initial decomposition rate of plant residues correlated broadly with indices of bulk chemical composition
    - verified contradiction: molecules predicted to persist in soils have been shown to turn over more rapidly than the bulk of organic matter
  - Existence of humic substances yet to be verified by direct measurements
    - assumption: humic substances were though to comprise large, complex macromolecules that were the largest and most stable SOM fraction
    - verified contradiction: large components only a small fraction of total organic matter, dominance smaller & simple molecular structures
  - Root-derived carbon is retained in soils much more efficiently than aboveground inputs of leaves & needles
  - Physical disconnection: soil volume occupied by micro-organisms considerably less than 1%
- Ecological implication: molecular structure of plant inputs & OM with more secondary role in determining carbon residence time compared with biotic & abiotic components

@hobbieControlsCarbonStorage2000
- AIM: review & meta-analysis on factors influencing carbon turnover in high-latitude soils to predict response to global change
- Temperature: (+)* mean annual temperature, but only ~15% variation
- Moisture: NS precipitations but (+)* drainage (topography)-> low oxygen availability in saturated soil
- Substrate quality (lignin content): growth form + temperature explained ~50% variation -> decompo rate deciduous & herbaceous >* evergreen >* moss

@frouzEffectsSoilMacro2018
- AIM: review on the effect of soil fauna on litter decomposition and soil organic matter stabilization
- Priming effect theory: decrease C stock through mineralisation following a sudden source of DOC
  - "fauna that consumes food with much higher C:N ratio than in their own bodies my contribute to the release of DOC into the soil": DOM with high C:N ratio -> DOC flush -> high microbial activity & respiration
  - however experience tends to indicate that overall fauna rather decreases DOM C:N ratio
- TAKE-HOME: 
  - SOM dynamics x soil fauna context-dependent & divided into 3 categories
    - direct effect on C mineralisation, often but not always small -> can increase or decrease C sequestration depending on faunal activity & soil conditions
    - effect on microbial activity resulting in mineralisation, mobilisation or immobilisation of nutrients -> can increase or decrease C sequestration depending on faunal activity & soil conditions
    - effect of fauna on fluxes between various SOM pools -> affected by the capacity of the pools & degree to which that capacity is filled
  - in soils with high SOM content (e.g. peat soils), soil fauna may promote C mineralisation while in mineral soils with low SOM (e.g. post-mining or abandoned agricultural fields) fauna activity may promote sequestration

@davidsonTemperatureSensitivitySoil2006
- AIM: review on temperature sensitivity of carbon decomposition
- TAKE-HOME: "a significant fraction of relatively labile SOM is clearly subject to temperature-sensitive decomposition, but another significant fraction of SOM remains under environmental constraints that often obscure the intrinsic temperature sensitivity of its decomposition"

@garcia-palaciosClimateLitterQuality2013
- AIM: meta-analysis to quantify effect sizes of soil fauna on litter decomposition rates & interaction with climate & litter quality
- Soil fauna (+)* across all biomes: exclusion soil fauna reduced decomposition rate by 35% globally, by 30% in agro-ecosystems & 47% in humid grasslands
- Contribution environment

@holtFoodProductionEcosystem2016

@byrnesInvestigatingRelationshipBiodiversity2014
- AIM: meta-analysis to compare four approaches to characterise multifunctionality & its relationship with biodiversity based on pan-European BIODEPTH experiments -> **classic to review methods & pros/cons when assessing multifunctionality**
- Multifunctionality approaches in research
  - "single function": based on collection of functions, ask qualitatively whether more functions achieve higher values in diverse mixture than at lower levels of species richness -> univariate responses with direct information about each individual function, but without quantitative assessment
  - "turnover": whether different sets of species promote different functions -> can quantify fraction of species which contribute to one or more functions but does not consider negative effect, does not directly measure multifunctionality & requires extensive data
  - "averaging": single metric estimating average value of multiple functions achieved in a given assemblage or plot -> indicate average effect of diversity on functions but cannot distinguish between two functions at similar levels neither one function at high level against a function at low level, & single function can have large impact
  - "threshold": tallies number of functions which quantitatively exceed some pre-defined threshold of functionality in a given assemblage/plot -> measure of how diversity simultaneously influences multiple functions, but arbitrary choice of threshold, magnitude of each function imperfectly captured (whether they pass threshold by small or large margin)
-> multiple threshold approach (*described in article*)
  - minimum threshold - lowest threshold where diversity begins to have an effect -> % maximal functioning at which multifunctionality becomes influenced by changes in species richness
  - maximum threshold - value beyond which the slope first declines to be not significantly different from zero -> upper threshold beyond which diversity has no effect on multifunctionality
  - threshold of maximum diversity effect - value where diversity has its strongest effect
  - realised maximum effect of diversity - strength of relationship (slope) where diversity has strongest effect -> maximum observed effect size of species richness on number of functions surpassing threshold
-> diversity as strong driver of multifunctionality if minT is low, maxT is high & both Tmaxdiv & Rmaxdiv are likewise high

@hectorBiodiversityEcosystemMultifunctionality2007
- AIM: meta-analysis on effect of set of species favourable for selected ecosystem processes on provision of ecosystem services in experimental grasslands across Europe (BIODEPTH experiments)
- Set of influential species according to services ranged from 3.2 to 6.6 species, with only marginally significant difference between services & experiments
- still some differences: wood decomposition from 1 to 4 species, while cotton decomposition from 2 to 11 species & above-ground biomass from 4 to 8 species
- average overlap in set of influential species over a pair of processes ranged from 0.19 to 0.49 across experiments but not significant
- turnover in most important species influencing ecosystem processes ranged from 0.57 to 1.00
- trend number of required species for cumulative combination of ecosystem processes -> log curve with different slopes according to experiment -> all positive but saturating
- slopes with no clear saturation point reached with the highest turnover rate, & slopes with obvious saturation rate with the lowest turnover rate
- TAKE-HOME: different sets of species affecting different ecosystem processes, so higher biodiversity should be able to support ecosystem multifunctionality, even if the threshold between complementarity & redundancy varies across regions

@allanLandUseIntensification2015
- AIM: to assess biodiversity, functional composition & ecosystem services on 150 grasslands of different land-use intensities (German Biodiversity Exploratories) according to different multifunctionality scenarii
- METHOD: threshold-based approach -> score on each service according to whether they pass a certain threshold as a certain fraction of the maximum level across all plots -> a certain loss is acceptable but below a certain threshold loss is unacceptable & functioning is impaired
- Relationship multifunctionality x land-use intensity -> overall coherent across regions
  - when high weight on provisioning services (production only), clear positive increase of multifunctionality with increase LUI
  - weakening of relationship & decline of slope to neutral along with introduction of more ES
  - negative relationship when objective was to optimise cultural services
- Plant species richness x LUI X CWM specific leaf area -> depends on regional productivity
  - no relationship in fertile grasslands
  - in average and less fertile grassland, increase LUI decreases species richness and increase SLA
  - correlation species richness SLA - strongly negative less fertile < negative average < no correlation high
- Direct & biodiversity-mediated LUI -> depends on regional productivity
  - weak indirect through richness & SLA << direct LUI in most productive region
  - most effects negative (except for production) in most productive region
  - for low productivity stronger indirect (positive) on production side & stronger (negative) direct on cultural side
  - for moderate stronger direct (positive) on the production site & stronger indirect (negative) on the cultural side
  - Indirect effects through SLA always positive in low productive region
- Difference between species richness & SLA
  - for moderate, indirect effects best explained by changes in species richness
  - for low, indirect effects best explained by chances in SLA

@wilsonWeakStrongMultifunctionality2008
- AIM: to discuss multifunctionality concepts in relation to decision-making in agriculture at the farm-level
- Agricultural transitions:
  - non-linearity over time - agricultural post-productivism does not necessarily follow sequentially from & replace productivism
  - spatially heterogeneous - not all geographical locations affected the same way
  - structure-agency inconsistency - "structure" & "agency" nont equally affected by transitions
- Debate between authors whether productivism/post-productivism dichotomy should be transcended or whether we keep it but reframed it accordingly to definitions productivism/non-productivism as post-productivism, as such, is not the opposite of productivism
- Multifunctionality thus viewed as "a spectrum bounded by productivist and non-productivist action and thought enabling a normative conceptualisation of weak, moderate & strong multifunctionality pathways for individual farm-level transitions"
- "strong" multifunctionality observed indicators (examples): 
  - local & regional embeddedness by actors
  - high environmental sustainability through relocalisation
  - low farming intensity & productivity
  - high symbolic value of food with additional value for rural regions
  - diversification farming activities
  - more likely to be weakly integrated into global capitalist market
  - substantial mental changes through open-minded farming & rural populations
- "strong" multifunctionality as "best" multifunctionality or with best "quality" with regards to environment, farmers wealth and well-being and also "moral"
- multifunctionality funnel: potentiality depends on range of enabling factors, with for example lowland farms with more transitional potential than upland farms -> thus range of opportunity may decline, even if quality should be reachable either way
- part-time farmers: often moderately multifunctional development pathways -> lack time & commitment for purely productivist but also to move farm completely towards purely non-productivist end.
- on the strongest multifunctionality side -> subsistence farms, particularly in the South, but which are often multifunctional by necessity/custom rather than choice. On the other hand, small economically marginal farms in developed countries are more often on the weak or moderate side as they have to maximise production in order to stay economically viable
- if drivers for adoption of multifunctionality pathways among small and economically marginal farms often differ depending on development level, multifunctionality drivers for highly globalised and well capitalised farms are increasingly converging around the world -> easier to "tip the balance" from strong to weak multifunctionality or vice versa, while on large highly capitalised farms the transition is more likely to be gradual 
- influence of ownership: 
  - owner-occupiers with most control & flexibility over multifunctionality decisions
  - multimember ownership usually slower the process and influence potential pathways as path dependency also depends largely on rapidity of common decision-making structures
  - for farmers renting lands, pathways influenced by external decision-making constraints which brings no less quality per se but more constraints and slower transitions
- **to continue section 3**

@dramstadIntegratingLandscapebasedValues2001
- AIM: explore relationship between landscape and associated values such as biodiversity, cultural heritage & human appreciation through appropriate indicators, based on case-study from Norway
- 3Q programm - initiated by the Norwegian Ministries of Agriculture and Environment in order the monitor changes in the agricultural landscape and to identify effects of policy and measures pertaining to this landscape -> multidisciplinary approach
- Biodiversity: breeding birds, vascular plants, butterflies & bumblebees -> both birds and plant species richness correlated with landscape heterogeneity, but no significant relationships for insects
- Cultural heritage: linked to landscape structure through farm buildings, historical boundaries between farm ownership, fields systems & cultivated & wooded areas (likely to be affected by farming intensification) -> number of grave-fields/grave-mounds correlated with landscape heterogeneity
- Visual appreciation: important elements of landscape are openness (grain size), complexity, topography & presence of anthropogenic structures
- Issues encountered: 
  - common conceptual definition of heterogeneity across disciplines
  - very demanding process, with high level of commitment from participants
- Limitation of land-cover based maps: only 2D, missing vertical structure and temporal dimension
- Take-home: landscape-based ecological analysis could be used for cultural and aesthetic analyses, with shared indicators and methodology

@bjorkhaugMultifunctionalAgriculturePolicy2008
- AIM: to transcend productivism & post-productivist duality and propose multifunctionality concept to compare the two extremes market-oriented liberalistic Australian against market-protected small-scale Norwegian
- Productivism 
  - refers to both agricultural policy & practice which are input intensive & maximise production of commodities
  - existed previous to WWII but ideology exploded after -> closely tight to the level of support from authorities through subsidisation, price guarantees & protectionists policies
  - always higher exploitation of natural resources & inputs -> high environmental impact to be expected
- Post-productivism - less straightforward than productivism
  - followed overproduction crisis of 1980s -> policies to reduce agricultural production, budgetary coasts & environmental externalities
  - social issue: shift farmers from knowledgeable architects of land to destroyers as consequence of intensive agriculture -> increasing gap between rural & agriculture with new groups & interests/lobbies gaining influence
  - agricultural production moved into free, liberalised, marked, with emphasis on consumer demands + incentives towards environmental-friendly practices rather than general support for agricultural production
- Multifunctional agriculture
  - paradox of enhancement of local planning control & conservation practices on one side, & further intensification & conservation of food chain through global & deregulated market
  - multifunctional concept encompasses complexity of production modes across different spatial & temporal scales
  - OECD "working definition" - "key elements of multifunctionality are the existence of multiple commodity and non-commodity outputs that are joinly produced by agriculture - and the fact that some of the non-commodity outputs exhibit the characteristics of externalities or public goods when markets for these goods do not exist or function poorly"
  - but term mostly used on the scope of liberalism and conflict at the "bureaucratic" level as considered to interfere with global market -> should transcend this to use this concept to build rural & environmental sustainability
- Agricultural policies in Norway - global market & trade influence got stronger in the 1990s, with subsequent deregulation & capitalism
- Multifunctionality concept in Norwegian policies
  - first mention in research in 1998, with focus on food preparedness, rural policy, environmental issues, production of food and fibre -> multifunctionality referred to additional outputs/functions of viable "traditional" agriculture, including long-term food security, viability of rural areas, cultural heritage, land conservation and maintenance of agri-biodiversity
  - some protections on Norway's side compared to EU, with some limitations on the free trade for agriculture and fishery products within the European Economic Area
- Multifunctional agriculture in Norway
  - assumed at the policy level, with public incentives & still strong regulations compared with neighbours
  - though in practice, government encourages for effectiveness & rationalisation to be more competitive for international trade and demand for cheaper food (so rather specialisation), but at the same time support organic farming & added value -> intensification of productivist lands & multifunctional land use extensive farming systems (hay-making, grazing)
  - farmers in favour of multifunctional goals but fear cuts in financial support
  - 80% Norwegian population wants to keep agriculture at present level to preserve rural communities, Norwegian food production & cultural landscapes
  - most Norwegian farmers believe competition with non-regulated market unsustainable

@bennettLinkingBiodiversityEcosystem2015
- AIM: review & opinion on three main issues affecting the incorporation of ES research into decision-making
- How are ES co-produced by socio-ecological systems?
  - Identify the role of biodiversity & other forms of heterogeneity in maintaining multiple ES
    - disentangle the effects of different dimensions of biodiversity on services at different spatial & temporal scales
    - more comprehensively account for responses of ecosystem function to multi-dimensional anthropogenic environmental forcing
  - Understand the effect of landscape & seascape heterogeneity on ES supply & test how innovative land systems, spatial planning & policy can be used to ensure more optimal landscape configurations
  - Assess the role of path-dependence & legacy effects in the supply of multiple ES (e.g. threshold effects, cross-scale effects...)
  - Understand the function of social systems in ES supply, including technological interventions, human management...
- Who benefits from the provision of ES?
  - Understand the diversity of stakeholders, their benefits from ES & their preferences for valuing ES
  - Identify spatial patterns of ES use & benefits (spatial mismatches, North-South unbalance...) using for instance spatially explicit methods (e.g. participatory GIS)
  - Identify temporal dynamics of ES use & supply
- What are the best practices for the governance of ES?
  - Characterise how institutions & agents influence the supply & distribution of ES -> requires novel hybrid methods which address the structural & functional dimensions of institutions, the preferences & capacities of agents & the integration of both with the biophysical understanding of ES
  - Identify tools, models & processes to support efficient, equitable & sustainable decision-making processes which account for feedbacks in complex socio-ecological systems (applicability, collaborative learning)
  - Understand the socio-political processes that create, support or constrain transformative pathways towards equitable, efficient & sustainable governance of ES
- From science perspective, 2 key improvements needed
  1) more integrative collaboration across social sciences, natural sciences & the humanities is required to address the challenges implied by the fact that ES are supplied & distributed by complex socio-ecological systems -> beyond multi-disciplinarity, need for integrated, transdisciplinary approaches
  2) the scientific community working on ES science alone cannot provide a full response to all of the key needs of policymakers & decision-makers -> need for knowledge co-production including local knowledge & habitus

@costanzaTwentyYearsEcosystem2017
- AIM: review on 20y of research on ES since 1997 including debates, learning processes & recommendations
- Definition ES: ecological characteristics, functions or processes that directly or indirectly contribute do human well-being: that is, the benefits that people derive from functioning ecosystems [@costanzaValueWorldsEcosystem1997; @millenniumecosystemassessmentmeaEcosystemsHumanWellbeing2005]
- Cascade concept (EF -> ES -> benefits -> values): not really supported by the authors because of 1) the introduction of human "perception" constraining benefits & values, thus limiting the reach of the ES concept & 2) the implied linearity which is not representative of the complex ecosystem-human dynamics
- Alternative:
![](illustrations/costanzaTwentyYearsEcosystem2017_ES-diagram.png)
- Classification systems:
  - MEA: United Nations Environmental Programme (UNEP) in 2001 + later The Economics of Ecosystems and Biodiversity project (TEEB)
  - Common International Classification of ES (CICES) - developed to provide a hierarchically consistent & science-based classification to be used for natural capital accounting purposes
  - The Final Ecosystem Goods & Services Classification System (FEGS) & National ES Classification Systems (NESCS) - developed by the US Environmental Protection Agency
- Valuation
  - On the principle of attributing value to nature: there is always at least implicit value anyway (even when only focusing on intrinsic value of nature) & nature is not always the most valuable thing to preserve (e.g. school, home, hospital...) -> thus better be explicit & transparent to highlight trade-offs
  - Limitation of the economic valuation & methods based on aggregation of individual & self-assessed welfare (e.g. willingness-to-pay): 1) individual welfare poorly representative of the comprehensive sustainable human well-being concept which depends on multiple environmental, sociological & cultural factors across community, society & life support system scales; 2) individuals do not perceive as accurately what contribute to their well-being
  - Value types:
    1) sustainable scale (*Homo naturalis*) representing whole system preferences & requiring medium discussion level & high level of scientific inputs
    2) fair distribution (*Homo communicus*) representing community preferences & requiring high discussion level & medium level of scientific inputs
    3) efficient allocation (*Homo economius*) representing current individual preferences & requiring low discussion & scientific input levels
  - Research progress including combination of valuation methods such as "integrated valuation" or "participatory valuation"
  - Approaches to aggregate values to larger scales
    - basic value transfer: assumes constant values over ecosystem types
    - expert modified value transfer: adjusts values for local ecosystem conditions using expert opinion surveys
    - statistical value transfer: builds statistical model of spatial & other dependencies
    - Spatially Explicit Functional Modeling: spatially explicit statistical or dynamic systems models incorporating valuation
  - Range of uses for ES valuation
    - raising awareness & interest: based on total values or macro aggregates, appropriate for regional to global scales with low precision needed
    - national income & wellbeing accounts: based on total values by sector & macro aggregates, appropriate for national scale with medium precision needed
    - specific policy analyses: based on changes by policy, appropriate for multiple scales with medium to high precision needed
    - urban & regional land use planning: based on changes by land use scenario, appropriate for regional scale with low to medium precision needed
    - payment for ES: based on changes by actions due to payment, appropriate for multiple scales with medium to high precision needed
    - full cost accounting: based on total values & changes by business, product or activity, appropriate for regional to global scales (international corporations) with medium to high precision needed
    - common asset trusts: based on totals to assess capital & changes to assess income & loss, appropriate for regional to global scales with medium precision needed
- Main institutions & programs
  - Millenium Ecosystem Assessment (MEA) - report, 2005
  - The Economics of Ecosystems & Biodiversity (TEEB) - report, 2008
  - Ecosystem Services Partnership - network, 2008
  - Intergovernmental Science-Policy Platform on Biodiversity & ES (IPBES) - network, 2012
  - Wealth Accounting & Valuation of ES - World Bank-led network
  - Natural Capital Project (NatCap) - academic partnership which developed, among others, the InVEST tool
  - Natural Capital Coalition (NCC) - business network, 2014
- Perspectives: concepts widely accepted but practical applications still limited by:
  - inconsistent approaches to ES modelling, assessment & valuation
  - expense of applying sophisticated enough methods to adequately answer questions
  - lack of appropriate institutional frameworks
  - mistrust or misunderstanding of science

@heinzeFarmDiversityFine2022
- AIM: to investigate ecosystem service delivery of different land use scenarii in mexican rural landscape (farms 4.6-47.6 ha), based on transdisciplinary approach
- Scenarii
  - S1 - intensified cattle ranching (agriculture): expansion + intensification across farms into riparian area first & montane forests second
  - S2 - land use zoning (land sparing): 50% farms with removal grazing + reforestation in upland forests (intensely) & riparian areas (moderate) while 50% allocated to intensified grazing
  - S3 - integrated agroforestry practices (land sharing): reforestation riparian (intensely), upland (lightly) & in agricultural lands, extensive grazing maintained across the area
  - S4 - forest restoration (reforestation): reforestation riparian (full) & upland (moderate) with extensive cattle grazing
- ES indicators
  - Forage production:
    - agriculture >* baseline >* land sharing & sparing >* reforestation
    - farm size: small farms with weaker S1 increase & stronger S2-4 decrease (-40;31;61%)
  - Firewood stocks: 
    - reforestation >* all 
    - farm size: under 25% change for all
  - Resin production: 
    - land sparing >* all >* agriculture
    - farm size: large with stronger S1 decrease (-30%) while small with stronger S2 increase (31%)
  - Tree cover: 
    - reforestation >* land sparing & sharing >* baseline >* agriculture
    - farm size: small with stronger S2 & S4 increase (25;34%), S1 decrease strong for both sizes (-26% small; -35% large)
  - Riparian corridor: 
    - reforestation >* land sharing >* baseline & land sparing >* agriculture
    - farm size: small with very high S3-4 increase (149-227%) even if large still substantial (43-87%), while large with stronger S1 decrease (-48%)
  - Tree diversity: 
    - reforestation & land sharing >* baseline & agriculture >* land sparing
    - farm size: small stronger S3-4 increase (29-27%)
- TAKE-HOME: ES trade-offs similar but magnitude very different across farm sizes (e.g. riparian corridors)

@dunningEcologicalProcessesThat1992

  - Landscape composition - relative amount of each habitat (dominance, relative richness, diversity)
- Landscape complementation - how far apart are patch types providing necessary **non-substitutable** resources within the landscape (e.g. foraging, winter roost, breeding)
- Landscape supplementation - how far apart are patch types providing necessary **substitutable** resources with the landscape -> population could be sustained on a "too small" patch if similar are close-by
- Source/sink relationships - productive patches as sources of emigrants for less productive patches -> increase of total population with new sinks, but the more sinks the fewer sources are found
- Neighbourhood effects - influence of contiguous patches higher than more distant patches & edge effects

@dixonhamilCrossscaleContradictionsEcological2016
- AIM: to review & compared methods for cross-scale analyses & highlight the effect of spatial  heterogeneity in macrosystems
- Extrapolation issues when not integrating spatial heterogeneity when dealing with coarse spatial scales
  - spatial transmutation: assuming that relationships revealed from aggregated data can be used to make predictions about the individuals used to devise these aggregated data
  - modifiable areal unit problem: statistical anomaly when changing size of spatial unit when analysing data collected over large areas (remote sensing)
  - zone effect: bias due to placement of spatial units
  -> cross-scale contradictions most problematic when conducting analyses at scales differing from those of data collection
- Existing methods
  - scale choice: "to identify the characteristic scale of response by modeling the relationship between the response variable & explanatory variables of interest" -> easier said than done both from data collection & analysis perspectives
  - upscaling: 
    - conditions: no collinearity among explanatory variables, linear relationships at finer scales & no shift from linear to nonlinear relationships across scales
    - if assumptions not met & spatial heterogeneity known is the sole source of spatial transmutation, expected values from nested subsections can be used to derive corase-scale estimates
  - downscaling: hierachical Bayesian models -> assume that the scales of data are nested & defines the model through a hierarchy, but unable to account for missing explanatory variables which have strong influence on response variable
- Proposed statistical approach
  - "From a statistical point of view, the contradiction means that the fitted models are an insufficient representation of the underlying ecological process or processes"
    - only linear terms included when there should be higher orders
    - absence of explanatory variables significantly impacting the modeled response variable
  - spatial heterogeneity usually only partially accounted for in statistical models due to the ignorance of all possible contributing variables 
    - "how to account for the factors which drive spatial heterogeneity in a given ecological process without explicitly knowing all the contributing factors ?"
    -> to consider spatial heterogeneity driven by latent random variables as such in mixed effects models & random fields
- Mixed effects model: associate fixed (explanatory variables associated with the entire population) & random (important factors driving spatial heterogeneity) effects by dividing larger study regions into smaller subregions each with independent random slope & intercept estimates for the modeled ecological process

@nashDiscontinuitiesCrossScale2014
- AIM: conceptual framework underlying the discontinuity hypothesis in ecological system to address multi-scale interactions
- Conceptual framework
  - hierarchy theory: ecosystem structure & dynamics dominated by the influence of a small set of organisms & abiotic processes operating at specific temporal & spatial scales -> "each level in this nested hierarchy of variables is controlled by processes sufficiently different in speed & size to introduce discontinuities in the distribution & pattern of ecosystem attributes"
  - discontinuity hyp: "where ecosystem patterns are persistent over ecological time scales, biological processes unrelated to the original structuring processes will become entrained by and adapted to the pattern across scales" -> e.g. organism attributes may adapt to discontinuous landscape pattern which reflect resource opportunity, but these are mediated by scale interaction organism/landscape which are correlated to body size
- Discontinuity vs emergent neutrality
  - emergent neutrality hyp: competitive interactions alone can generate a discontinuous body mass distribution -> locations of the aggregation of species result from stochasticity so differ according to community
  - discontinuity: locations of the aggregation of species result from interaction biota with habitat structure so similar across sites with same habitat
- Identification of scales
  - issue arbitrary choice: 1) may not be relevant for all species/processes of interest & 2) relevance of theoretical models to empirical results may be masked due to scale mismatch
  - Opportunities discontinuity analysis
    - differentiate between systems exhibiting scale invariance of variables/processes vs discrete intrinsic scales
    - reduce the arbitrariness of scale selection & increase the likelikood of designing effective multi-scale studies
    - delimit the appropriate scales for ecological surrogates
    - predict congruence in the response of species to disturbance or environmental drivers
    - partition out variance associated with scale effects prior to running other analyses
  - evaluation discontinuities body size distribution relatively well studied, but less for other community traits/characteristics (e.g. biomass)
- Identification of nonlinearities & regime shifts: "Temporal changes in the structure of body size distributions could be used to forewarn of reorganisation within a system leading to a new regime."
- Functional distributions
  - nonrandom patterns: "functionally similar species with same body size aggregation subject to stronger interactions than those operating at different scales"
  - redundancy: scale-specific distribution of functions may be used to quantify the degree of cross & within scale redundancy of an assemblage
  - resilience: 
    - importance of considering species abundance, not reflected by functional distribution
    - connectivity: "Characterising distributions of function across scales will highlight the likely spatial extent of mobile links and identify vulnerabilities due to a narrowing of the range of scales over which an assemblage is functionally effective"

@petersCrossScaleInteractions2007
- AIM: to provide a cross-scale interaction framework focusing transfer processes and spatial heterogeneity at the intermediate between broad & fine-scale patterns **LA BASE**
- Cross-scale interactions = processes at one spatial or temporal scale interacting with processes at another scale that often result in nonlinear dynamics with thresholds
- Related framework
  - "finer scales provide the mechanistic understanding for behavior at a particular scale, and broader scales provide the constraints or boundaries on that behavior"
  - scale domain characterised by a certain stability of relationships between patterns & processes -> thresholds are a regime shift driven by change in pattern/environmental driver
  - cascading bottom-up consequence as one threshold crossing at one scale can unfold the crossing of overarching thresholds -> e.g. wildfire
    - trigger: lightning strike on tree
    - initial fire spread: depends on individual tree properties (dryness, density & type of leaves)
    - patch spread: interaction tree properties with patch characteristics (connectivity, size)
    - multi-patches: interactions fuel load characteristics connecting patches & within patches & individual tree properties
    - processes hierarchy over time: starts with tree scale, to within-patch variation, to among-patch connectivity
    - at very large scale: land-atmosphere interactions producing fire-generated weather overwhelming local fire dynamic processes
  -> **hierarchical interaction among processes at different scales**
- Framework for cross-scale interactions and changing pattern-process relationships
  - Hypothesis: "intermediate-scale properties of transfer processes and spatial heterogeneity determine how pattern-process relationships interact from fine to broad scales"
  - Scales: fine (individual) - intermediate (group) - broad (landscape, region, globe)
  - Effects from changes in external drivers or disturbances:
    - bottom-up effect followed by top-down feedback overwhelming fine & local processes: e.g. livestock grazing lowering competitive ability grass -> encroachment by shrubs -> dispersion rather than competition drives colonisation to nearby patches -> broad-scale wind erosion can enter the loop & overwhelm competition & dispersion processes into deepening grass/shrub imbalance
    - direct top-down effect overwhelming fine & local processes: e.g. regional long-term drought
  - Linear extrapolation worth considering only if
    - intermediate transfer processes & spatial heterogeneity not important
    - negligible transfer processes but high spatial heterogeneity -> stratification area to obtain homogeneous, independent cells where linear extrapolation can be used to aggregate within cells
  - But "when connections among spatially heterogeneous areas via transfer processes are important, then a spatially-explicit approach is needed that accounts for the rate, magnitude & direction of materials being transported" -> single scale observation insufficient
  - Effects transfer processes & spatial heterogeneity
    - amplification: when rate of change in system properties increases nonlinearly -> e.g. wildfire, emphasized by heterogeneity (connectivity & cascading events)
    - attenuation: when rate of changes decreases through time -> e.g. tsunami, with wave amplitude decreases as wave form increases, thus heterogeneity becomes increasingly important as distance from sismic event increases
- Methodologies & design
  - "measuring responses at multiple scales simultaneously & then testing for significant effects of variables at each scale"
  - stratified-cluster experimental designs
  - statistics: non-stationarity & nonlinear time series analysis

@scherrerDisentanglingProcessesDriving2019
- AIM: to assess the effect of fine-scale spatial partitioning in comparison with habitat filtering & limiting similarity on trait-based assembly of alpine grasslands at coarse plot (2 x 2 m) and fine subplot (20 x 20 cm) scales
- Definition
  - Habitat filtering: "only species sharing similar adaptation to cope with prevailing environmental conditions can co-occur" -> trait convergence
  - Limiting similarity: "species show limiting similarity (i.e. alpha-niche differentiation = differences in the traits related to the ways the species compete for a common resource) to coexist" -> trait divergence
  - Fine-scale spatial partitioning: "species coexist at the plot level because they segregate in space due to endogenous or exogenous spatial heterogeneity" -> segregation of traits among subplots within a plot
- Assembly processes
  - Habitat filtering: *predominance at coarse scale for all traits (except for leaf dry matter content) but not at fine scale
  - Limiting similarity: 
    - *predominance at fine scale for all traits
    - *effect at coarse scale for all traits except vegetation height
  - Trait-dependent
    - convergence: strongest for vegetation height & leaf nitrogen content
    - divergence: strongest for specific leaf area & leaf dry matter content
  - Habitat filtering & limiting similarity as opposing forces driving functional patterns, unrelated to species richness
  - Fine-scale partitioning: no predominance but *correlated with limiting similarity
- Environmental gradients
  - only vegetative height (R^2^ = 0.6) & specific leaf area (R^2^ = 0.42) varied with elevation, while leaf nitrogen content & leaf dry matter content completely independent
  - only weak effect at plot level & negligible at subplot level for both habitat filtering & limiting similarity
  - trends from combined growth traits: habitat filtering strongest in productive low elevation habitats while limiting similarity strongest in cold climates at high elevations
  - no signal fine-scale spatial partitioning
- TAKE-HOME:
  - habitat filtering influence prominent at plot scale and reduce at finer scale to the favour of limiting similarity into driving trait-based assembly
  - only marginal influence of environmental gradients

@lundholmPlantSpeciesDiversity2009
- AIM: review to investigate plant species diversity in relation to environmental heterogeneity across different scales from both observational & experimental studies
- 3 assumptions required for positive heterogeneity-diversity relationships (HDR)
  - factors defining species niches must be heterogeneous at scales that could alter individual plant responses and community-level patterns
  - interspecific variation in dispersal abilities does not interfere - all fitted species can reach available microsites
  - each individual occupies a patch perceived as homogeneous -> difference between coarse-grained (bigger scale than individual spatial extent) which promotes diversity, and fine-grained (smaller than individual spatial extent) heterogeneity which can provoke different responses
- most observational studies (34/41) reported positive HDR -> only species richness as a measure of diversity except for 4 studies
- common predictors of diversity - heterogeneity of topography, substrate & soil type
  - response to soil nutrient heterogeneity either positive or neutral
  - response to topographic heterogeneity under 200 m^2^ either negative or NS, more often positive above 600 m^2^
- no evidence of spatial scale "threshold" above which HDR become positive
- no noticeable relationship between focal scale & shape/magnitude of HDR across experimental studies
- competing hypothesis - available energy hypothesis
- TAKE-HOME: most studies support positive HDR, confirming niche importance & strength compared with neutral distribution patterns, but relationship not universal nor homogeneous

@ketzlerClimateNorway2021
- AIM: chapter from book on geomorphological features of Norway [@beylichLandscapesLandformsNorway2021], focusing on climate
- "as Norway is located in the zone of westerly winds, the increase in elevation along the Norwegian coast forces the rise of moist air masses" -> higher cloudiness & precipitations on the coast
- Gulf stream provides both warmer currents & buffers annual temperature range
  - summer: temperature ocean > air -> higher evaporation rate which creates moist air masses
  - winter: temperature ocean < air
- combined effect of distance to sea, elevation and geographical location
- precipitation gradient coast-inland 
  -> peak of precipitation on western zones "in front of" Scandinavian mountains (e.g. Brekke at outer Sognefjord) or lower mountain areas inland (< 1400 m)
  - high variation range in mountain and inland areas
- the coast
  - "numerous islands, inlets and peninsulas at different sizes and, thus, land and water next to each other in different scales and in combination with different relief situations."
  - sea breeze effect - rising warm air from ground collides with cooler sea air that moves horizontally (advected) inland -> temporary changes of wind direction & humidity conditions
  - reflection of sunlight on water with increased radiation input on waterfront
  - reduced/amplified cooling by surrounding warm/cold water bodies
  - reduced land-sea differences with windy conditions or combined sea & mountain breezes
- the fjord
  - "U-shaped valleys partly below sea level" -> differences between outer fjord and inner fjord
  - inner fjord regions
    - "Föhn wind" effect (dry, relatively warm descending leewards - usually protected - mountain slopes)
    - but overall low wind speed
    - mild climate, with winter mostly >0C, high spring temp, moderate summer temp -> fruit cultivation
    - inland freshwater fjords -> frozen surface in winter react like land areas
    - great lakes -> local climate effects (buffer daily temperature cycle, increase humidity, sea breeze circulation)

@austrheimPlantDiversityPatterns2002
- AIM: observational study to compare diversity of plant functional types along an elevational gradient in southern Norway -> 4 levels L1 500-550; L2 735-775; L3 895-960; L4 1150-1260
- Q1 - What are the main patterns of species diversity (alpha, beta, gamma) in vascular plants, bryophytes and lichens along the gradient?
  - vascular plants
    - gamma - total vascular species richness decreased with elevation at both 10 m^2^ & 500 m^2^ scales
    - alpha - significant peak at elevation L2 at quadrat (0.25 m^2^) scale, but no significant relationship richness x elevation
    - low relative contribution of alpine species at L1 & L2, while high contribution of lowland/subalpine species at L3 & L4
    - similarity highest at L2 & L3, higher number of exclusive species at L1 & L4
  - bryophytes & lichens
    - gamma - increase with elevation at 10 m^2^ scale (except for L2)
    - alpha - significant increase with elevation at quadrat & subquadrat scales (0.0156 m^2^)
    - similarity highest at L3 & lowest at L4; higher number of exclusive species at L4
- Q2 - Can patterns of species richness within and among levels be explained by environmental variables?
  - vascular plants species richness
    - decreased with potassium, cryptogam layer cover, phosphorus
    - increased with slope, field layer cover, herb biomass
    - negative linear relationship with PC1 (positively correlated with nutrients, LOI, bryophyte & lichen cover)
    - positively but NS related to PC2 (positively correlated with slope, pH & Ca)
  - bryophytes & lichens species richness
    - decreased with soil temperature, herb & total biomass, percent open surface, field layer cover, slope and heat index
    - increased with LOI, percent cryptogam layer cover, wood biomass
    - strong positive relationship to PC1, indifferent to PC2
- Q3 - Can vascular plant species richness be explained as an area effect?
  - continuous gamma diversity decrease along elevation vs no trend at small scale -> relative importance of area changes with elevation
  - lower estimated marginal mean at L3 compared to L1 & L2, at L4 compared to L2
  
@kleinebeckerEffectsGrazingSeasonal2011

  - B: grazing-tolerant short-lived perennial with poor dispersal & competition
  - C: grazing-tolerant long-lived perennial with poor dispersal & slightly better competition
  - D: grazing intolerant long-lived perennial with good dispersal
  - E: grazing intolerant very long-lived perennial

  - decrease 100% to 20%: low effect on A, B, C biomass

@parsonsSpatialHeterogeneityGrazing2003
- AIM: review of basic plant-grazer interactions from bite to flock leading to system spatial heterogeneity
- 1. How far can fine scale interactions explain origin of phenomena at larger scales
  - sequential (deterministic) vs random biting
    - at low stocking rate (< 5 LU/ha), intake not affected by grazing regime (enough resources & no competition between grazers)
    - at high stocking rate however
      - if deterministic: same patches grazed at same rate with fixed regrowth window -> progressive decrease of biomass
      - if random: some patches would escape grazing by "chance" & have more recovery time -> increase temporal variation regrowth & biomass availability
  - grazing preferences x vegetation structure
![](illustrations/parsonsSpatialHeterogeneityGrazing2003_GrazingSelectionVGStructure.png)
  - foraging costs
    - costs increase 1) with degree of selectivity & 2) if the the preferred food is less abundant in the vegetation
    - trade-off benefits of eating a given diet component against costs of selecting for it
- 2) Animal responses to potentially prohibitive costs
  - How spatial distribution influence encounter rate
    - if random walk: 
      - encounter rate patch: more smaller patches > fewer larger patches
      - encounter rate food: greater variance with fewer larger patches -> longer periods for both preferred food & no food
    - if targeted walk: for any abundance/cover, probability encountering patch depends on size field of view x grain pattern of aggregation
  - Learning & spatial memory
    - when small searching area both naive & trained animals should be more successful to find preferred food, but variation in memory capacity will have small effect
    - benefits of spatial memory greatest in intermediate searching areas
    - less effect spatial memory in largest searching areas implying limitation
  - Area-concentrated searching within patches: "turning" control efficiency coarse-grained > fine-grained & increase with intra-patch resource density
  - How observed foraging success (closer to random) could mismatch expected success (driven by learning & spatial memory)
    - more difficult to exploit knowledge as patch number increases & seeking minimum distance travel path an effort in itself -> experiments needed to confirm if animal make rational planning or graze closer to at random
    - when revisiting areas, they may respond to spatial patterns of replacement rate of resources -> affected by temporal dynamic of regrowth
    - social interactions between animals creating conflicts
- 3) Foraging as a group & effect on individual foraging
  - Costs & benefits group foraging
    - benefice: shared discovery & vigilance
    - downside: intra-specific competition 
      -> risk of returning to a patch which has been depleted by other animals
      -> can encourage animals to leave prematurely a current patch
    - social behaviour -> preference to graze close to peers rather than going further to preferred patch
  - Scale may affect preferences due to social interaction
    - no grouping effect may be observed under a minimum space per individual
    - hyp: foraging efficiency may decline at large spatial scales because of environmental complexity & constraints of group foraging, but also at small spatial allocations when animals are "forced" into groups
- 4) To what extent do animals come close to achieving the optimal solution
  - Optimal foraging modelled at bite scale -> Shape of regrowth curve & subsequent harvest supply depend on initial patch state (residual after previous bite) & duration regrowth
  - Model outputs
    - sequential or random grazing being as individuals or group would lead to suboptimal combinations of residual patch states & defoliation intervals: low stocking rate with too long defoliation intervals vs higher stocking rate with low residual patch states
    - grouped animals with regulated movements (fencing) & rotation -> possible to combine severe defoliation with long recovery intervals

@koernerChangeDominanceDetermines2018
- AIM: meta-analysis of 252 herbivore exclusion experiments worldwide to investigate plant diversity-habitat productivity relationship
- Hypothesis: herbivore-induced changes in the competitive environment determine the response of plant biodiversity to herbivory irrespective of productivity
  - when reduction dominance palatable species -> increase biodiversity
  - when promotion dominance herbivory-resistant species -> reduce biodiversity
- Herbivory x richness along gradients
  - *+ relationship along ANPP, but low explanatory power (R^2^~0.08) & effect neutral to positive even at lowest productivity
  - no *correlation with annual precipitation
  - strong *- relationship against Berger-Parker dominance -> coherent with hypothesis
- Explanatory pathways of plant richness response to herbivory
  - ANPP model (chi2 = 11.8)
    - explanation change species richness *R^2^ = 0.13*
    - precipitation (+)*** ANPP (0.49)
    - ANPP (+)** change in richness (0.27)
    - site-level species richness (-)** change in richness (-0.21)
    - grazing pressure (-)* change in richness (-0.15)
    - herbivore richness, domestication & feeding guild NS
    -> *stronger (+) effect of grazing in high productivity & lower (-) effect of grazing pressure*
  - Berger-Parker dominance model (chi2 = 14) -> best fit
    - explanation change species richness *R^2^ = 0.31 -> best fit*
    - precipitation (+)*** ANPP (0.49)
    - site-level dominance (-)*** change in dominance (-0.47)
    - change in dominance (-)** change in richness (-0.32)
    - site-level dominance (+)** change in richness (0.26)
    - domestication (+)** change in dominance (0.23)
    - ANPP (+)** change in richness (0.18)
    - grazing pressure (-)** change in richness (-0.18)
    - herbivore richness & site-level species richness NS
    -> *strong (+) effect of grazing when high dominance & (-) correlation between change in dominance & richness*
  - precipitation as proxy for ANPP model (chi2 = 2.93)
    - explanation change species richness *R^2^ = 0.11*
    - feeding guild (-)*** change in richness (-0.37)
    - herbivore richness (+)** change in richness (0.19)
    - domestication, grazing pressure & site-level species richness NS
  - precipitation as proxy for dominance (chi2 = 4.33)
    - explanation change species richness *R^2^ = 0.26*
    - site-level dominance (-)*** change in dominance (-0.54)
    - change in dominance (-)*** change in richness (-0.36)
    - feeding guild (-)*** change in richness (-0.26)
    - feeding guild (+)*** change in dominance (0.23)
    - site-level species richness (-)** change in dominance (0.2)
    - herbivore richness (+)** change in richness (0.18)
    - domestication (+)* change in dominance (0.11)
    - grazing pressure (-)* change in richness (-0.11)
    -> *strong (-) relationship site-level dominance (no-grazing) & change in dominance*
- Simulation role of palatability in richness/dominance relationship
  - if dominant species palatable or 50% being palatable, very similar to observations = strong (-) relationship
  - if dominant species not palatable, relationship less clearly defined
- TAKE-HOME
  - neutral to positive effect of herbivory on richness even at low productivity, which increase with productivity
  - stronger role of dominance in determining plant richness response to grazing compared with productivity/precipitation
  - stronger effect of grazing on dominance in sites with high dominance

@milchunasGeneralizedModelEffects1988
- AIM: to propose a model based on environmental moisture & grazing evolutionary history to explain grazer-grassland interactions across a wide range of communities
- 3 types of grasslands: climatically determined, successional or agricultural -> model constrained to climatically determined
- Standard assumption that intermediate disturbance level hypothesis results from reduction in competitive exclusion -> but grazing can also affect:
  - the relative importance of mode of competition
  - the longevity of the change in competitive relationships after the grazing event -> temporal window influenced by environmental factors (water, nutrients availability...) & relaxed of competitive interactions
- Model assumption: "the response of plant communities to grazing is mediated through an interaction of convergent or divergent selection pressures along the moisture gradient and factors relating to a tolerance or an intolerance of grazing along the evolutionary-history-of-grazing gradient

@briskeRotationalGrazingRangelands2008
- **tres cool :-)**
- AIM: review implications & research of rotational vs continuous **rangeland** grazing systems
- Why complicated to come up with general recommendations when it comes to grazing systems
  - 1) wide range ecological variation from inherent & management sources
  - 2) farmer/manager commitment ability (ownership, revenue...)
  -> if only considering ecological implications, per default rotational management would be considered as more beneficial than continuous - but managerial implications can actually drive both the best and the worst of any grazing system
- Core principles of vegetation response to grazing:
  - 1) Chronic, intensive grazing detrimental to plant growth & survival
  - 2) Primary productivity can be increased by moderate grazing and decrease under severe grazing
  - 3) Forage quality is often improved by frequent grazing
  - 4) Species composition of plant communities can be modified in response to the frequency, intensity & seasonality of grazing
    - mitigation competition by selective grazing
    - grazing patchiness
- Results from experimental research for similar stocking rates
  - plant production/standing crop: 17/19 reported no difference
  - animal production per head: 16/28 reported no difference, 10/28 reported continuous > rotational
  - animal production per unit land area: 16/28 reported no difference, 10/28 reported continuous > rotational
  -> no better production under rotational compared with continuous
- Why high expectations?
  - overestimated benefits of rotational grazing: following degradation rangelands, continuous grazing criticized on the same ground as high intensity
  - environmental constraints: different ecological dynamics (hydric limitation) & managerial requirements in rangeland systems compared with mesic pasture systems that have high & consistent plant production

@olffEffectsHerbivoresGrassland1998
- AIM: review on herbivore impact on grassland plant diversity to propose a new conceptual model linking plant species richness to grazing -> **classic**
- Effect herbivores on plant species richness depends on 
  - type & abundance of herbivore species in particular environment -> usually (+) at low/moderate stocking rates, (-) at high stocking rates
  - spatial/temporal scales at which diversity is measured or affected
  - interaction herbivore body size x scale diversity -> local effect large herbivores at larger spatial scale
  - productivity system -> grazing more optimal on high productive fields
- Mechanisms plant species richness
  - balance between local colonization & extinction rates of species
  - herbivore body size could explain direction, magnitude & scale of effects
  - plant div/herbivore relationship depends on environmental gradients
- existing concepts
  - resource partitioning
  - local colonization from regional species pool
  -> merging both following island biogeography theory, with colonization depending on regional species pool & extinction from local competition
  -> "ultimate effect of herbivores on plant diversity might depend on their relative impacts on biomass & reproduction of dominant plant species, the density & type of regeneration sites & the supply of propagules from rare plants"
- Environmental gradient
  - soil fertility & precipitation gradients
  - plant tissue which influence palatability depends on ratio resource supply
  - classification habitats 4 categories according to wet/dry, productive/unproductive
  - wet infertile
    - dominant plants with low tissue nutrient concentrations but productive enough to induce light competition
    - grazing by large grazers (livestock) may shift local competition from light to soil nutrient allowing more species to coexist
  - wet fertile
    - dominant plants productive, important light competition 
    - strong competitors (tall) more likely to be unpalatable due to stem:leaf ratio to all but large herbivores
    - grazing opens canopy & enhance grazing-tolerant species over tall species -> high density of grazers supported by fast regrowing species would affect non-grazing tolerant species

@rookMatchingTypeLivestock2004
- REVIEW: grazing-pasture biodiversity mechanisms with focus on livestock type
- Sward heterogeneity
  - selective defoliation resulting from dietary choices
  - directional/random trampling favouring gap-colonising species
  - patch-like nutrient deposition locally increasing competition
  - endo- & exozoochory
- Animal behaviour
  - animal strategy does not always follow resource optimisation
  - relative importance "currencies" (limiting factors) depends on habitat deficiencies, animal health (parasitism), antiparisitic properties of some plants (selective adaptation)
  - time effect: observed daily routines maybe linked to digestibility
  - spatial effect: animal routines mostly observed in uplands where animals free to move around
- Body size: small herbivores usually have higher energy/gut size ratio than large herbivores & thus select higher quality food
- Feeding category
  - mouth size: sheep & goats able to be more selective on plant material than cattle, so they can pick biomass in less desirable area where cattle would avoid it overall
  - mouth/teeth shape: sheep, goats & horse able to graze closer to ground compared with cattle
- Breed
  - even though rustic breeds perceived as better suited for grassland conservation in terms of both biodiversity & animal performance, strong experimental evidence still lacking
  - breed differences could be "simply" explained by body size differences, even if different behaviour patterns already observed
- Learning & experience
  - preferences can be maintained from early-age experiences, but duration quite variable from a few weeks to whole grazing season
  - hints that breed x experience effects but not much evidence
- Economical implications
  - rustic advantage: reproduction performance maintained when underfed in winter
  - higher prices result not only from breed itself but most importantly whole system associated with it
- Perspectives
  - to determine innate vs learnt behaviour & selectivity
  - to identify currencies which drive animal strategies in different circumstances
  - to improve & generalise our understanding of animal effect on spatial distribution of foraging
  - to develop socio-ecological frame of agricultural landscape

# MEASURING BIODIVERSITY IN AGRICULTURAL LANDSCAPES

@palmerSmallscaleEnvironmentalHeterogeneity1990
- AIM: to discuss a correction between observed species distribution in a quadrat, which has its own range of conditions, and the extrapolated distribution along the gradient

@kokEuropeanBiodiversityAssessments2020
- AIM: to review methodologies used to assess effect of livestock on biodiversity in Europe
- Scales of study: field > landscape > farm > genetic > field element
- Indicators according to organisation level
  - genetic: DNA, breeds, populations
  - species: 
    - abundance & richness - most commonly used, with focus on plants & within plants vascular. For arthropods, beetles, butterflies & moths most commonly studied, and within them Carabidae and dung beetles.
    - traditional diversity indices - Shannon index most commonly used
    - novel diversity indices - mean species abundance (= relative abundance of originally occurring species compared with undisturbed ecosystem), potentially disappeared fraction (= relative change in species richness compared with undisturbed semi-natural habitats), multidiversity (relative richness of multiple taxonomic groups)
    - composition & function: most studies used ordination (C-CA, NMDS), with i.e. Ellenberg indices for ecological niche, functional traits & diversity..., other used Community Specialisation Index (specialist vs generalist bird species)
    - qualitative scoring system: systems specific to each studies
  - landscape: structure & habitat: coverage by different height classes/plant categories; richness, abundance & Shannon index for land cover/land use types; spatial organisation landscape
- Summary impact livestock on biodiversity
  - 36% negative, 21% positive, 15% both, not applicable/neutral 26%
  - difference between food production function, where more intensive was never only positive, & conservation function, where almost half cases positive impact
- TAKE-HOME:
  - focus on direct effects, gap on indirect effects (feed, water use) -> life cycle approach pertinent, particularly under socio-ecological perspectives
  - when conservation approach, more relevant to evaluate the degree to which systems can be preserved -> thus novel indices
  - novel indicators with low cover in academic literature but already big impact in policy-making -> key to properly understand underlying assumptions for selecting appropriate indicators & make the right interpretation
  - seemingly validated concepts in relation to livestock impact: intermediate disturbance hypothesis & winner/loser species

@leprovostContrastingResponsesBelowground2021
