@duelliBiodiversityEvaluationAgricultural1997
- AIM: to highlight challenge assessing local/regional biodiversity in agro-ecosystems & propose framework for standardised biodiversity estimates
- 3 types of comparison to assess biodiversity of an area
  - contribution to broader scale biodiversity - e.g. low-species rich mires but with high specialisation level which host rare red-listed species
  - comparison in space - to neighbouring sites/areas
  - comparison in time - long-term monitoring -> sensitive for sustainability
- measures of site-specific biodiversity
  - instead of more commonly used plant & birds, arthropods as surrogates -> contribute to 90% genetic variability
  - though warning towards "specialist-conservationist" perspective, with intensive research for exhaustive inventory -> may be interesting for national-wide biodiversity (e.g. rare species), but to date no "best correlating arthropod group in comparison with overall biodiversity in agricultural field/area"
  - widely used group is carabid beetles, but indicative value relatively weak as species number & distribution relatively similar across biotopes -> more accurate would be spiders & staphylinids
  - limit data collection - in terms of efficiency, 3 weeks in spring & 2 weeks in summer optimal -> for 1st period, a good indicator is one week after onset of full flowering *Taraxacum officinale*
- landscape mosaic pattern as surrogate for regional biodiversity -> equilibrium theory of island biogeography (biodiversity on inland positively correlated with island area & negatively correlated with distance to nearest continent)
  - limit of this approach in agricultural landscape - fragmentation & isolation seemingly not most limiting factors, but habitat quality
- mosaic concept for local/regional biodiversity, better suited than island biogeography
  - habitat variability - number biotope types per unit area -> the higher, the broader is spectrum of genetic pool
  - habitat heterogeneity - number of habitat patches & ecotone length per unit area -> biodiversity increases with number & size variation of patches, which also increases ecotones & edges
  - surface proportions natural, semi-natural & intensely cultivated areas
- TAKE-HOME: assessment regional biodiversity should rely on mosaic concept including all parameters

- Research trend over time

  - farmer research networks

@lamarqueHowEcosystemServices2014
- AIM: outcomes from a RP feedback game with farmers to explore how ES cognition mediates feedback from environmental change in farmers' behaviour in a mountain grasslands system
- Scenarios: drastic climate change & local socio-economic perspectives; intermittent (favourable conditions) & international; drastic anticipation with current socio-economic context
- Farmer knowledge
  - overall knowledgeable of the ES concept, & most ES known except nitrate leaching & carbon storage
  - recognition mutual interactions (e.g. plant diversity, flowering)
  - manuring: not associated with nitrate leaching but with increase forage quantity & quality
  - grazing: negative effects on aesthetics & plant diversity & decrease litter quantity
  - climate: influence rainfall, temperature & elevation on forage quantity
- Farmer values: forage quality > plant diversity > forage quantity > water quality > aesthetics > litter quantity > flowering onset > nitrate leaching > carbon storage
  - forage quality: desirable for herd welfare & parts of the herd with higher needs such as lambs or dairy cows
  - forage quality & quantity: contribution farm economy
  - plant diversity: contribution forage quality &/or aesthetics
  - litter quantity: variable, with positive short-term effect on vegetation regrowth (frost protection, fertilisation) but negative long-term effect with litter choking out vegetation & affects forage quantity & quality
- Farmers behaviours in scenarii
  - manuring: stopped in drastic-local, increased in intermittent-international & variable in drastic-anticipation
  - mowing vs grazing:
    - drastic-local: mostly grazing, with half farmers stopped mowing & engaged with fodder buying in winter
    - Intermittent-international: mostly mowing
    - Current practices: farmers organised their land management around spring grazing & mowing because summer alpine meadows large enough to ensure flexibility forage resources
- Contextual factors: constraints topography for mechanised mowing & manuring, economic (distance to farm)
- TAKE-HOME: 
  - some ES not part of farmer knowledge, thus by principle not considered, but institutional mechanisms (e.g. carbon credit) led some farmers to take it into consideration
  - some ES known but with low value or farmers considering not having enough knowledge to integrate them in decision-making: e.g. perceived influence mowing date on flowering onset (thus affecting forage quality & quantity) but did not consider themselves to adjust date for maximising ES delivery
  - some ES both knowledge & values, with reasoning on synergies & trade-offs between multiple ES: e.g. manuring first for forage quantity but also species diversity & forage quality
  - both direct & indirect feedback, with farmers adapting to familiar constraints (e.g. drought) but also new information (carbon credits)

@mcginlayThreatAbandonmentSocioecological2017
- AIM: to assess the risk of abandonment of high nature value grasslands in relation with farmer interviews
- Candidate availability: at most meadows, at least some degree of difficulty in recruiting & retaining farmers to undertake agricultural management operations because of 1) replacement for retirement & 2) ageing farmer population
- Farmers' perspectives on meadow value: 
  - highly variable, but generally acknowledged the validity of biological, cultural & landscape aspects of meadow value
  - most importance on agricultural value (hay quality/quantity)
- Barriers to farmers' agency in meadow management
  - restriction associated with agri-environment schemes (e.g. hay cut) usually associated with reduction hay quality
  - controversy about manuring, about which conservationists are critical but farmers attached for cultural (traditional) & productivity arguments
  - animal welfare & hygiene legislation which restrict the movement & mixing of cattle herds: financial + administrative barriers
  - management delivery models & compensation schemes
    - licensee: payment from farmer to landowner -> most common but also least beneficial for farmers
    - non-economic mutual arrangement, but no farmer benefice of agri-environment funding
    - bought-in contractor service -> the default option to respond to lack of candidates
    - owner-manager
- Profitability: only marginal with very unstable economic situation because of market prices

@ianniRevitalizingTraditionalEcological2015
- AIM: to investigate on the presence & evolution of TEK in a community of a World Heritage site in Italian Alps threatened by encroachment
- General ecological knowledge (assessed from plant species identification) limited in the community
- Negative trend of biodiversity-related knowledge transmission between generations
- Strong relationship between increasing disconnection (physical or psychological) & independence of livelihood from agricultural & wild systems & significant intergenerational losses of ecological knowledge -> loss of knowledge indicator loss of ecological control

@wehnAdaptiveBiodiversityManagement2018
- AIM: combining traditional ecological knowledge with scientific knowledge to assess the adaptative management approach of semi-natural hay meadows in Western Norway
- Norway's Action Plan for Hay Meadows - monitoring of biodiversity targets & introducing sustainable management of the most biologically valuable semi-natural hay meadows across Norway -> subsidies for the farmers when HBV + voluntary 5-10 years management plan following authorities guidelines
- Method
  - Social survey - farmer interviews about historical, floristic & ecological knowledge linked to hay mowing with ecologist & social scientists
  - Ecological survey 
    - all plant species, classified as TEK indicators, semi-natural specialists or neither
    - assessment of biodiversity conservation by management made on species assemblages & semi-natural grassland specialists
    - assessment of pertinence mowing time - phenological stages of TEK indicators & semi-natural specialists the week before mowing date
- objective 1 - Success of the APHM approach on the short-term
  - successful to involve land owners and managers (collaboration perspective)
  - but more limited in making farmer's point of view evolve -> farmers very attached to the "vision of a non-overgrown farm", which was the main reason of their collaboration, rather than the "diversification of the landscape"
  - no obvious positive effect of scheme, but prevented managements with potential negative influence (what the farmers would have done without APHM alternative)
- objective 2 - Revival of historical practices
  - big issue of fragmentation and concentration of hay meadows, due to loss of summer farming practices
  - most properties (10/14) without livestock, while combination of hay & livestock was typical of small-scale farming in Norway -> what the cut grass should be used for when there is no livestock anymore
  - strong reliance on pluriactivity = diversified incomes, which has impacted the use of specific material/facility for hay-cutting
- objective 3 - Long-term sustainability
  - although high species richness within the meadows, low turnover between them (meadows rather homogeneous) -> problem might be linked to fixed cutting dates, which are not part of traditional practices
  - ageing farming population, with not much potential for succession at all so even less for keeping traditional practices
- objective 4 - role of TEK in meeting ADHM goals
  - limited TEK (e.g. indicator species) of respondents, especially younger, though a 70y suggested the gap was already more than one generation ago
  - in absence of such knowledge, more difficult to involve farmers in the making of the management plan. But some farmers did develop "endogenous" knowledge through the management process
  - Still possible to use recorded TEK as indicators, but for biodiversity rather than agricultural production (historic use)
- TAKE-HOME: during threat to hay-meadows diversity & integrity due to ageing population and loss of traditional practices (missing market for hay) -> practices still pertinent from an ecological perspective, but do not address current socio-ecological conditions even if farmers are overall willingful. APHM has helped in the short term, but long term much more challenging

## TRANSDISCIPLINARITY

@lacombeDesigningAgroecologicalFarming2018

@altieriLinkingEcologistsTraditional2004
- AIM: review on traditional farming systems and linked agroecosystems that could feed ecological theories -> transdisciplinary research
- Smallholder knowledge and skill has developed by centuries of experience, without research, a way to self-sustain their communities while keeping high-biodiversity agroecosystem
- This farming could be used as models in this race for sustainable use of land -> need translation of principles into practical strategies for natural resource management
- Agricultural landscapes developing from indigenous knowledge are managed for different usages, so they are multifunctional by nature and allow local food self-sufficiency
- place-specific, co-evolution with nature and culture
- Similarities for most traditional agroecosystems:
  - high species number
  - high structural diversity in time and space
  - exploitation of the full range of local microenvironments
  - maintenance of closed cycles of materials and waste through efectice recycling practices
  - complex biological interdependencies, resulting in a high degree of natural pest suppression
  - dependence on local resources and human and animal energy, thereby using low levels of input technology and resulting in positive energy efficiency ratios
  - use of local varieties of crops, wild plants, and animals
- "Most farmers have an intimate knowledge of their surroundings, especially within a small geographical and cultural radius. This local expertise cannot be matched by the generalized knowledge of the ecologist, yet the ecologist's sophisticated training cannot be matched by the experiential knowledge of local farmers.
- What can ecologists lean from farmers
  - traditional farming systems usually mixed-systems with complex interactions between different ecological and human compartments -> great playground to understand processes of natural fertilisation, pest control (services)
  - higher productivity, stability and resilience of polyculture systems thanks to the mechanism of facilitation

# ECOLOGICAL METHODOLOGY

## STOCHASTICITY VS DETERMINISM

@conradiResourceAvailabilityDetermines2017
- AIM: to experimentally assess the effects of soil nutrient supply on niche-based selection vs stochasticity in determining species composition of early-successional temperate grasslands
- Alpha diversity: decreased across all treatments, but magnitude depended on intensity
  - smaller decrease under low & moderate nutrient supply
  - stronger decrease under high nutrient supply
  -> end experiment: alpha diversity low & moderate supply >* high
- Grass relative abundance increased over year with high supply
- Gamma diversity (overall species number across plots) low & moderate >~20% high supply
- Beta diversity -> contradictory results between indicators 
  - Jaccard's Index: increased (NS) over years with high supply -> composition should thus rather be driven by stochasticity or dispersal limitation rather than filtering
  - Raup-Crick dissimilarity (control for probabilistic sampling effect leading to high beta div values when alpha low): under high supply considerably more species than expected by random chance vs* low approached species number expected by random chance
- Processes
  - low supply: low temporal turn-over (Jaccard) but dissimilarities approached zero during succession -> turn-over most likely resulted from ecological drift
  - high supply: first stochastic assembly, then transition to selection-dominated system
  - moderate supply: intermediate temporal turn-over + slightly unimodal relationship dissimilarities with time, with as high alpha as low supply but increase grass abundance -> temporal turn-over driven by slow replacement of less competitive species
- TAKE-HOME: ecological succession in nutrient-poor grasslands mostly driven by stochastic patterns while nutrient enrichment imposed deterministic filter favouring species with greater ability for light competition

## SCALE

@cadotteDispersalSpatialScale2005
- mostly dispersal focused, so not most important now

@borcardDissectingSpatialStructure2004

@ettemaSpatialSoilEcology2002

@leiboldMetacommunityConceptFramework2004

@chanetonDisturbanceEffectsPlant1991
- AIM: to assess the effect of observational scale and level of species abundance hierarchy when studying both slow underlying disturbance (cattle grazing) and shock disturbance (flooding)
- Method
  - observational scale: stand (~1 ha) vs patch (~5 m)
  - dominance hierarchy: weighted richness dominants N2 (reciprocal Simpson) vs intermediate N1 (exponential Shannon) vs full N0 (species richness)
- Stand diversity
  - Dominance x grazing -> diversity higher in ungrazed but N2 sharper than N1 -> more dominance concentration under grazing
  - flood x grazing -> flood decreased richness in ungrazed, with sharper for N1 (intermediate species more affected), & increased in grazed, with a bit more for N2 (dominant species favoured) -> N1 richness similar for both grazing conditions after flood
- Patch diversity
  - Dominance x grazing -> N2 similar between grazing regimes, N1 ungrazed < grazed (less intermediate species in ungrazed), N0 ungrazed < grazed
  - flood x grazing -> decreased N0 & increased N2 for both grazing regimes, N1 decreased in ungrazed & increased in grazed
- Relationship N1 x sample length 
  - regression sharper (from lower div but gets higher) in ungrazed plots compared with grazed plots -> higher heterogeneity in ungrazed plots
  - when flood, regression ungrazed same as grazed
- TAKE-HOME: effect of disturbance & interaction between disturbances will vary according to grain of study and weighted diversity index

@brownImportanceScaleEvaluating1989
- AIM: to explore the importance of scale when assessing effect of herbivory on plants -> **un classique !**
- Scale of observation - already known processes change shape & interaction when observer moves along scale
  - Single plant - herbivory impact may be death, changes in resource or biomass allocation, photosynthetic rates, reproduction, morphology -> thus may impact competitivity of grazed plant against others
  - Community - three-ways interaction: plant diversity & sward structure constrain herbivory - community composition & structure constrain plant response to herbivory - herbivory constrain both individual plant & community
  - Environment - constrain grazer patterns/choices and thus indirectly affect community
- *"The time interval during which one chooses to make measurements and the frequency of measurements during the interval will determine the significance of what is perceived."*

@allenConfusionScaledefinedLevels1990
- AIM: to propose a new framework in order to isolate scale of observation from organisational levels -> **un classique pour expliquer la difference entre niveaux d'organisation du vivant et echelle**
- Organisational levels are not scale-dependent: what define them is not the size, but the relationship
- Thus unidirectional organisational scale not relevant to describe ecological complexity, as it only shows a very specific case which is far from being a general rule
- Background & foreground: rather than size/scope, thinking ecosystem fluxes of material & energy along time frame -> slower more widespread fluxes and processes are the context for more local processes with a short turn-over time
- Communities as "interference patterns of organism occupancy of euclidean landscapes over the short and the long terms" -> interference = pattern which emerges through interaction effects of two or more waves somewhat out of phase, usually because of slightly different periods in the separate waves
![](illustrations/Allen&Hoekstra1990_ScaleOrganisation.png)

@hustonLocalProcessesRegional1999
- AIM: to review/conceptualise variation of diversity according to scales of ecological processes
- main questions before considering local vs regional control of ecological patterns
  - what is the appropriate scale for seeing effects of local processes
  - how are regional processes manifested at the scale of ecological measurements
- assumption: patterns at large spatial scale result from regional processes, while patterns at small spatial scales result of either local or regional processes
- warning about the term "local" when defining large study area (e.g. 50 x 50 km) which by nature encompass heterogeneity at scale large enough to match with beta-div rather than alpha-div
- characterisation "regional" processes
  - effects of geophysical properties of a region (climate, geology, size, age) on ecological processes occurring at either local or regional scales
  - ecological or evolutionary processes (migration, invasion, extinction) that occur uniquely at regional scale
- limitation of species diversity
  - local extinction after disturbance, under low population growth rate likely to be induced by low productivity -> low end of productivity gradient
  - local extinction following competitive exclusion, under high population growth rate & few disturbances -> high end of productivity gradient
  - primary available regional species pool -> in-between of productivity gradient, where high variability of combination productivity x disturbance
- thus *warning extrapolation from local to regional* -> if any local sample at non-equilibrium conditions allowing high diversity, total species list will cover effect of local processes in other localities & lead to incorrect conclusion that regional influences are dominant over entire area
- TAKE-HOME - "any heterogeneity resulting from disturbances or variation in physical conditions will tend to obscure the negative effect of local processes on species diversity, and lead to the erroneous conclusion that local processes are unimportant for regulating diversity"

@denglerBiodiversityPalaearcticGrasslands2014
- Extremely diverse grasslands (particularly central Europe) can be explained by five preconditions: 1) Large evolutionary species pool; 2) Intermediate position along environmental gradients; 3) Landscape heterogeneity/mass effect; 4) Continuity of habitat patches in space and time; 5) Reduction of competitive exclusion
![](illustrations/Dengler.etal2014_ConceptScaleFiltersGrasslandFlora.jpg)

@siefertScaleDependenceVegetationenvironment2012
- AIM: to assess the effect of spatial extent and grain on the primacy of predictor variables on plant community composition
- Between the effects of fine-scale (e.g. edaphic) and broad-scale (e.g. climatic) factors on community data, the variance explained will depend differently on the extent and the grain of the survey. Fine-scale variation will be very high at small extent but will stabilize quickly on bigger areas, while broad-scale variation will be very low at first at increase with bigger extent. Both will decrease with higher grain, but it will be sharp and fast for fine-scale and slow for broad-scale. The influence of the latter can then be expected to increase with bigger spatial grain. There would then be a spatial grain threshold from which broad-scale variables take over fine-scale variables to explain species composition variance.
![](illustrations/Siefert.etal2012_ScaleExtentGrain_VarExp.jpg)
- New metric: multivariate effect size statistic MESS = average of correlation coefficients across multiple ordination axes, weighted by the amount of variance accounted for by each axis
- Predictor primacy - % most variance explained over total cases
  - Extent
    - <1 km^2^ (NS): / biotic (0) < 0% climatic & spatial (4) < 45% edaphic (20) < 50% disturbance (4) & topography (18)
    - 1-100 km^2^*: 0% biotic (8) & spatial (3) < 27% topography (15) < 33% climate (3) < 50% disturbance (10) < 57% edaphic (21)
    - 100-10 000 km^2^: 0% biotic (5) < 25% climate (8) < 29% spatial (14) < 33% disturbance (9) < 45% edaphic (29) < 53% topography (19)
    - >10 000 km^2^*: 0% spatial (4) < 8% topography (13) < 20% disturbance (10) < 36% climate (11) < 50% biotic (4) < 53% edaphic (17)
    - overall*: 12% biotic (17) < 16% spatial (25) < 27% climate (26) < 36% disturbance (33) < 37% topography (65) < 49% edaphic (87)
  - Grain
    - <50 m^2^*: 0% biotic & climatic (5) < 25% spatial (4) < 29% topography (14) < 33% disturbance (9) < 60% edaphic (20)
    - 50-200 m^2^*: 0% biotic (2), disturbance (2) & spatial (7) < 14% climate (7) < 48% topography (21) < 58% edaphic (26)
    - 200-1000 m^2^: 17% spatial (6) < 25% topography (16) < 36% disturbance (14) < 40% edaphic (25) < 57% climate (7) < 67% biotic (3)
    - >1000 m^2^: 0% biotic (7) < 25% spatial (8) < 29% climate (7) < 38% edaphic (16) < 43% topography (14) < 50% disturbance (8)
    - overall*: 12% biotic (17) < 16% spatial (25) < 27% climate (26) < 36% disturbance (33) < 37% topography (65) < 49% edaphic (87)
- Estimated extent threshold of 2000 km^2^ or 45 km linear distance -> from where plant distribution more likely to be explained by climatic factors (e.g. temperature) than edaphic factors (e.g. pH)

## ECOLOGICAL PREFERENCES & TRAITS

@broseConsumerresourceBodysizeRelationships2006
- AIM: to investigate body size ratio of consumer vs resource across habitats and organisms
- across all habitats & predator types: linear increase predator mass with prey mass
- predator/prey body size ratio across habitats
  - freshwater > terrestrial or marine habitats
  - no *difference among invertebrate predators
  - invertebrate prey >* ectotherm prey for invertebrate, ectotherm & endotherm predators

@wongTraitBasedEcology2019
- AIM: to build an arthropod-related conceptual framework for ecological traits
- Environmental properties such as habitat openness and moisture should not be considered as traits, as they are not measured on the organism, but rather defined as "ecological preferences"

## INDICATOR SPECIES

@tichyStatisticalDeterminationDiagnostic2006
- AIM: to compare and optimise fidelity coefficient phi and indval
- Phi correlation
  - Unlike Indval, Phi correlation coefficient depends on the size of the group, and an equalization step can be needed in case of different group sizes
  - Phi can be high for not very common species in target group if difference between relative frequency within and outside target group is large. On the other hand, if difference is small then even species with high frequencies in target group are given low phi values
- IndVal
  - Standard indval: very high weight to common species and lower weight to differences in relative frequency of species. But also possible to modify balance between fidelity and specificity
  - Unlike phi, no zero (when species frequency in target = in non target) and not possible to distinguish positive from negative fidelity 
- For small vegetation units of unequal size, equalized phi better characterised the vegetation units

## INSECT TRAPPING

@duelliBiodiversityEvaluationAgricultural1999

@shortEntomologicalCollectionsAge2018
- AIM: to list and describe available methods for insect data collection and evolution of the field with new technological advances

@bakerEvaluatingSpatialAutocorrelation2006
- AIM: tested for spatial autocorrelation and depletion within 99 m transects when using pitfall trapping for ground-dwelling arthropods
- Did not find spatial correlation within 99 m transects -> "beetle community dissimilarities were not consistently lower when traps were in closer proximity"
- importance to test for spatial autocorrelation on control site to validate the study design

@wardEffectsPitfallTrap2001
- AIM: tested trap spacing effect between groups with 1 m, 5 m and 10 m distance on ground-dwelling arthropod (all orders)
- No spatial depletion observed across treatments (no change in abundance)
- Difference in morphospecies richness for beetle between 1 m space and the other treatment, with rare morphospecies more affected
- No change in morphospecies composition. Change was explained by habitat factors and not trap spacing

@mommertzComparisonDVacSuction1996
- AIM: to compare sampling efficiency of D-vac, fenced and unfenced pitfall traps for beetles and spiders in agrosystem, with complementary lab experiment to compare activity and trapability of beetles from same genus
- D-vac overall with lower taxa number and abundance. D-vac samples dominated by Staphylinidae
- More individuals and higher biomass caught in unfenced compared with fenced traps -> bigger species more common in unfenced and smaller species most frequent in fenced. But overall result interpretation when comparing habitats no different
- In lab experiment, *Poecilus cupreus* more active and was caught quicker than *Poecilus versicolor*.

@schmidtCaptureEfficiencyPreservation2006
- AIM: to compare different pitfall trap liquids in specimen capture and preservation of ground-dwelling arthropods
- High evaporation rate of ethanol-based liquids
- Preservation specimens: pure water and ethanol-based with more damaged spider parts compared to salted water and ethylene glycol
- Catch numbers: overall arthropod abundance no different, but effect on spiders, springtails, dipterans & ground beetles. Number of ground beetle genera & spiders lower in salted water & ethanol-glycerin
- Hypothesis for difference in capture: specific gravity higher in salted water (SG = 1.18-1.20) which makes arthropod floating at the surface, and thus makes easier the escape of newly trapped individuals than can rest on them.
- Ethylene glycol recommended as non-volatile and preservative

@sunderlandDensityEstimationInvertebrate1995
- AIM: to review the different catching techniques to estimate the density of invertebrate predators in agroecosystems
- The most accurate term to characterize pitfall trap catches is "activity-trappability-density"
- Only "real" density estimation would be with a trapping web sampling design with concentric circles of traps at fixed distances from central point

@koivulaPitfallTrapEfficiency2003
- AIM: to investigate the effect of trap size, collection fluid and vegetation structure on Carabidae collection
- Fluid: ethylen-glycol more efficient
- Trap size: large traps collected more individuals
- Habitat type: difference in trappability of one species over four between clear-cut and forested stand, but no detected effect of surrounding field-layer vegetation

@wallinMovementsCarabidBeetles1988
- AIM: to study walking behaviour of different Carabidae species depending of the habitat and their feeding state
- Species would follow a correlated random walk in their preferred habitat (e.g. forest for *Carabus nemoralis* and *Pterostichus melanarius*)
- On the other hand, forest species would have a directed movement or burrowing activities in crop fields

@greensladePitfallTrappingMethod1964
- AIM: to test the efficiency of pitfall traps according to sampling setting and immediate surrounding in grass heath
- Traps with vegetation clipped 30 cm around captured overall more individuals than without clipping, but seemed to vary according to species
- Catching efficiency also could depend of litter depth, with catches of *Nebria brevicollis* diminishing with increasing litter depth (but not control experiment, so where is the trapping efficiency compared to the environmental preference?)

@melbourneBiasEffectHabitat2009
- AIM: experiment to test for vegetation structure effect within the immediate pitfall trap surrounding on ant catching
- Experimental design: non-modified, clearing of litter within 80 cm radius, clearing of all vegetation within 80 cm radius.
- Abundance: for 4 out of 5 common ant species, more specimens were caught when surrounding cleared, but some variations across species
- Relative abundance: for 3 out of 5 common ant species, effect of habitat structure. But no common trends and high variability between species responses.
- Occurrence frequency: overall 19 species, higher frequency with cleared habitat. 8 rare species over 10 (<10 occurrences) were only caught in cleared treatments.
- Species richness: higher in cleared treatments
- Community composition: clear and significant difference between non-modified and all-cleared treatments

@buchholzCoversInfluenceCapture2009
- AIM: to test whether the presence of roof affect the pitfall trap capture efficiency for different orders in grassland
- METHOD: 3 replicates for each treatment (not covered, white cover, green cover, black cover) on 14 x 14 cm lids on 5 grassland sites for 1 year (emptied once a month)
- No effect on species richness and abundance for both spiders & carabids
- No effect of roof on Carabidae species distribution, and no visible trend according to species habitat preferences (open vs woodland) contrary to spiders

@bellEffectsPitfallTrap2014
- AIM: bulding on from @phillipsEffectsHabitatStructure2005, to test the effect of lid transparency and habitat structure on catches of Carabid beetles in grassland
- METHOD: 3 treatments (opaque, semitransparent, transparent) on 15 x 15 cm lids + surrounding vegetation height effect (2.5 m radius) on 1 unique site
- EXP 1: 3 replicates for each treatment (only?) for ~15 days trapping -> 435 beetles
- EXP 2: 3 replicates for each treatment x surrounding vegetation height (0.5; 0.25; <0.1 m) for ~40 days trapping -> 1263 beetles
- Overall higher catch with higher transparency, but seems to differ according to vegetation height and beetle species
- Considering all species, trends are: no visible effect at low vegetation height, potentially lower efficiency of transparent at medium height, lower efficiency of opaque at high vegetation
- Different species response: *Agonum cupreum* with significantly less catches under opaque lids, while *Amara obesa* less affected overall and seemingly with higher catches under opaque lids

@phillipsEffectsHabitatStructure2005
- AIM: to test the effect of lid transparency and habitat structure on catches of Carabid beetles in regenerating stand of formerly clear-cut and burnt mixed boreal forest (trembling aspen ~2m height)
- METHOD: 3 treatments (opaque, semitransparent, transparent) on 15 x 15 cm lids + surrounding (2.5 m radius) vegetation height effect (2; 1; <0.1 m) on 1 unique site
- EXP: 3 replicates for each treatment lid x vegetation height for ~73 days -> 1216 Carabidae
- Temperature under roof significantly increased with lid transparency and with lower vegetation height
- Trends of higher catches of Carabidae with opaque lids with low surrounding vegetation, but not significant
- For two most abundant species, no effect either even if some trends of higher vegetation catch of *Sericoda quadripunctata* under opaque lids in low vegetation
- Significant vegetation effect (more Carabidae caught in lower vegetation) but no significant lid x vegetation effect
- Species composition affected by vegetation structure (high vs low & medium) but no effect detected of lid transparency

@baarsCatchesPitfallTraps1979
- AIM: to test pitfall trapping efficiency to capture beetle density on two model species & comparison square vs cup traps
- Close linear relationship between beetle density and year-round sampling for both species

@schirmelCaptureEfficiencyPitfall2010
- AIM: to determine how sampling interval (weekly, once every two weeks, monthly) affects efficiency of pitfall traps for different orders
- Number of catches significantly decreased with increasing sampling interval for Apidae, Araneae, Carabidae, other Coleoptera and Isopoda

@langeEffectPitfallTrap2011
- AIM: to compare efficiency of funnel vs conventional cups and diameter size on catches of Carabidae and spiders
- METHOD: 4.5 cm vs 9 cm diameter PVC traps, with and without funnel
- Carabidae abundance increased with size of trap and with use of funnel, but the number of species was not affected by any of this factor.
- Spider abundance (*) and species richness (NS) affected by trap size
- Cost-efficiency: better lower number of more efficient (bigger + funnel) traps.

@jansenHowManyVictims1979
- AIM: to model mathematically the capture of pitfall traps
- Model assumptions: 1) animals move independently (Brownian motions); 2) Boundary of pitfall act as absorbing or elastic barrier; 3) A fixed density of animals at t0 homogeneously distributed over finite area
- Model free parameters: 1) animal mobility; 2) animal reaction to pitfall trap; 3) initial density

@hohbeinPitfallTrapsReview2018
- AIM: building from @brownReviewExtensiveVariation2016 but with more literature resources, to review pitfall trap methodology and list differences in trap characteristics and sampling design
- Recommended standard design:
  - Nested design (funnel)
  - Diameter 9-11 cm
  - Transparent cup and funnel
  - Propylene glycol for preservation (non-toxic, contrary to ethylene glycol)
  - Transparent cover, 2-5 cm aboveground
  - Sampling intervals: 7 days or less
  - Trap distance: transect, every 10 m

@brownReviewExtensiveVariation2016
- AIM: to compare how different pitfall trap coloring (brown, green, white, yellow) affects arthropod catches from different orders
- Overall orders (NS): white > yellow > green > brown
- Significant difference for Apidae, Araneae, Carabidae & Diptera with more captures with white and then yellow traps.
